context: The salesman said to the customer, “The compressor is the core part of the refrigerator. Penguin uses the same high quality compressor as the Polar Bear. Since the price of a Penguin refrigerator is much lower than that of a Polar Bear, when you buy a Penguin instead of a Polar Bear, you can get the same cooling effect for less money.“
question: Which of the following, if proven, supports the salesman's conclusion?
A: There are more ads for the Arctic Bear refrigerator than for the Penguin refrigerator.
B: The refrigeration effect of a refrigerator is determined solely by the quality of its compressor
C: Penguin refrigerators sell more than Arctic Bears every year.
D: D: The refrigerator is a common electrical appliance in many homes
explanation: From the explanation that the compressors of the two brands are the same, the salesman concludes that the lower-priced brand will not only cost less, but also have the same refrigeration effect.

context: Male: If you become wind, I become rain. Female: I only like to bathe in the sun
question: Which of the following expressions is most similar to the woman's rejection of the man?
A: M: If you bloom, butterflies will come. Female: I'm not a butterfly.
B: M: If you do not leave me, I will be with you in life and death. Female: I just want to be alone facing the sea, with spring flowers blossoming
C: Man: If someone is chasing you, you say you have me. Female: You don't have me.
D: If you are the wind, I am the sand. W: Sandstorms give me a stuffy nose
explanation: The man points out the conditional relationship between“ turning into wind “and“ turning into rain “, while the woman's answer negates both and points out that there is a third option, that is, “I don't like wind or rain, I just like to bathe in sunshine“

context: A, B, and C are working on a logic problem. After checking the answers, A says,“ I did it wrong.“ B says, “A did the right thing.“ C said, “What I did was wrong.“ Unsure, he went to consult his logic teacher. After reading their answers, the teacher listened to the other three and said to them, “There is only one person who is right about what you said and your answers.“
question: Visible:
A: A is right, C is right
B: What A said is true, what B said is true
C: If B is right, A is right
D: if C is right, B is right
explanation: For this question, we can first apply the contradiction relation. A and B are contradictory relations, and there is one true and one false. Therefore, C's answer is false, indicating that C's answer is correct. Therefore, A's answer is wrong, which means that A is telling the truth, so choose.

context: Doctors have long believed that people with diabetes should limit their starch intake. Recently, in a large study, experts found that people with long-term diabetes consume less starch than people without diabetes
question: If overeating is the cause of diabetes, which of the following, if true, best explains the new findings?
A: Most people with diabetes intentionally control their dietary intake when they know they have the disease.
B: Type 2 diabetes is not serious and does not require much dietary control.
C: Only a small percentage of people with diabetes are correctly diagnosed.
D: Diabetes occurs most frequently in people with a family history of the disease.
explanation: Diabetes is caused by excessive diet, but diabetics eat less than normal people. Diet control is one way to explain this phenomenon.

context: The sole motive for an individual's action is to safeguard his or her personal interests. Therefore, safeguarding personal interests is the main factor affecting individual behavior.
question: Which of the following is true and most weakens the argument above?
A: Safeguarding personal interests is the sole motive of individual behavior, which is worthy of discussion.
B: Sometimes motivation cannot be the main factor influencing an individual's behavior.
C: An act that is in the interest of the individual may also be in the interest of the public good.
D: Individual behavior cannot be completely divorced from group behavior.
explanation: Premise: Safeguarding personal interests is the only motive for individual behavior Conclusion: Safeguarding personal interests is the main factor affecting individual behavior. The duplicate item of premise and conclusion: safeguarding personal interests, obviously to ensure the validity of the argument, the necessary hypothesis is: the motivation of personal behavior is the main factor affecting personal behavior, when weakened, the direct questioning of the hypothesis is the strongest.

context: “The principal of the school insisted that the students' failing grades were due to poor teaching by the teacher. Soon after the new term began, there were no more students who had failed their academic records the previous term. Therefore, the headmaster was pleased to see this as evidence that the quality of teaching in the school had improved.
question: Which of the following reasoning has a defect similar to the stem?
A: “Nutritionists maintain that the players' weight gain was caused by overeating. For a short period of time, all the players stopped overeating. As a result, nutritionists believe that the players will not gain weigh
B: The team members were complaining about the weight gain, but the nutritionist believed that the weight gain was only in the players' imagination and issued them weight charts for the past three months. Therefore, the nutritionist is pleased that complaints about weight gain have decreased
C: The manager maintained that the workers' complaints were due to the complexity of their work tasks. The manager simplified the work and the workers' complaints stopped. Therefore, the manager is pleased to think that the working conditions have improve
D: D) The manager maintains that the complaint was lodged by the workers as a result of undersaturation. A short time later, no complaints were filed at the plant. So the manager was pleased to think that it was because the workers' jobs were getting fuller and fulle
explanation: Step 1: Grasp the main information of the explanation. A: “The teacher did not teach well“ leads to B: “The student failed“; The quality of teaching is improved (the teacher teaches well) (A) the student passes (B). (A) The student passes (B). (B) A: Overeating (A) leads to weight gain (B), stopping overeating (-A) leads to weight gain. The resulting result is not a fact, but a judgment and therefore inconsistent with the reasoning of the question. B: Imagining (A) leads to complaints of weight gain (B), handing out weight tables (C) leads to complaints of weight loss (-B), is not consistent with the logical relationship of the problem, excluded; C: Complex work tasks (A) lead to complaints (B), simplified work (-A) and no complaints (-B) lead to an improved working environment (C), inconsistent logical relationship with the problem, excluded; D: Workload saturation (A) leads to complaints, enrichment is workload saturation (-A) → no complaints (-B), consistent with the logical relationship of the problem, is selected

context: The picture tube is the core component of any TV set. Brand P televisions use picture tubes of the same quality as brand T televisions. But Brand P sells at a lower price, so when you buy a brand P TV instead of a brand T TV, you're paying less for the same picture quality.“

D: P TV sets are sold more than T TV sets every day
explanation: First step, determine the question type. According to the word “support“ in the question, it is determined to strengthen the argument. Second, look for arguments and evidence. The argument: When you buy a P TV instead of a T TV, you are paying a lower price for a TV with the same picture quality. Argument: Brand P TVS use the same quality picture tubes as Brand T TVS, and Brand P TVS are sold at a lower price. 3. Identify the options. Item A: Make connections. The picture quality of a television is determined only by the quality of its picture tube. Brand P and brand T televisions use the same quality picture tube. Brand P televisions are sold at a lower price, so buying a brand P TV instead of a brand T TV is equivalent to buying a TV of the same picture quality at a lower price. B: No, it's not a good idea. P and T brands of TV sets are assembled in the same factory is not necessarily related to the quality. C) They are assembled in the same factory. The profit from selling P TV sets is less than that from selling T TV sets. It has nothing to do with the quality of the two brands. D) It is not necessary to make money from selling P TV sets. Brand P TV sets are sold more than brand T TV sets. B) The quality of the two sets is not clear. Therefore, it is necessary to choose A

context: “Before 1989, cultural relics were stolen seriously in our country, and many cases were stolen from major museums, and many precious relics were lost. After 1989, major museums installed a multi-functional prevention system with advanced technology, and such grand larceny cases decreased significantly, which shows that the multi-functional prevention system plays an important role in protecting cultural relics.
question: Which of the following, if true, most strengthens the conclusion above?
A: Among the cultural relics stolen in the 1990s was a precious artifact handed down from the ages.
B: Since the early 1990s there has been a marked rise in thefts of cultural relics from private collections and small pavilions
C: From 1989 to 1999, insurance premiums paid by major museums for important and valuable cultural relics in their buildings increased substantially
D: In the early 1990s, the theft of cultural relics was more serious in the north than in the South because the south had a more developed economy and more advanced methods of protecting cultural relics
explanation: The advanced multi-functional defense system plays an important protective role. The cases of theft of cultural relics still exist, while the cases of theft of museums with the system have dropped, while those of private collections and small pavilions without the system have risen, indicating the important protection role of the system.

context: Many people think of depression as two kinds of mental illness, and people with depression have a strong tendency to commit suicide. In the mid-20th century, medical research found that depressed people who committed suicide had lower concentrations of three neurotransmitters (serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine) in their brains than normal people. This led medical scientists to speculate that an imbalance in the concentrations of these three neurotransmitters caused depression
question: Which of the following statements, if true, provides the strongest support for the medical scientist's conclusion
A: Depression is not only a psychological disease, but also an organic disease.
B: A drug developed to balance the concentrations of these three neurotransmitters is effective in the treatment of depression.
C: Women and the elderly have a high incidence of depression.
D: It may be that depression causes an imbalance in the concentration of the three neurotransmitters mentioned above in the brain.
explanation: From the explanation that the concentration of three neurotransmitters in the brain of depressed suicide patients is lower than that of normal people, doctors conclude that the concentration imbalance of these three neurotransmitters leads to depression.

context: It is not impossible for some people to get into graduate school
question: Which of the following comes closest to the meaning of the above determination?
A: All of them may go to graduate school.
B: All of them are bound to fail to get into graduate school.
C: Some people may not get into graduate school.
D: All of them may not get into graduate school.
explanation: Opposition relation. “It is impossible for some to be admitted to graduate school“ is equivalent to: “It is inevitable that some will not be admitted to graduate school“. Therefore, it is not “it is impossible for some people to be admitted to graduate school“, it is equivalent to: it is not “it is inevitable that some people will not be admitted to graduate school“, it is equivalent to: “It is possible for all people to be admitted to graduate school“

context: During periods of high tectonic activity, new ocean basins around Africa, South America, and Europe began to expand, creating new Spaces. C: large-scale, long-term natural changes, or large short-term changes in the global greenhouse effect due to human activities, can have systemic impacts

explanation: First step, determine the question type. According to the word “support“ in the question, it is determined to strengthen the argument. Second, look for arguments and evidence. Argument: Global cooling or warming is just as bad. Argument: The sequestration of atmospheric carbon causes atmospheric carbon dioxide levels to fall, reducing the greenhouse effect and lowering global temperatures, with very serious consequences for Marine life. Step 3: Identify the options. A: Irrelevant. A. Global warming C. global warming C. global warming C. global warming C. global warming C. global warming B) Add to the argument. (B) “Global warming will lead to a crisis of Marine life“ means that the consequences of global warming are serious, and “similar crises have occurred in Marine life during periods of global cooling“ means that the consequences of global cooling are equally serious and reinforcing. C) What is the effect of global warming? C. The consequences of global warming are serious, but not compared with the consequences of cooling. D) The consequences of global warming are not obvious. (D) The climatic cooling over millions of years is difficult to relate to the rapidly changing modern climatic conditions -- climate warming. (D) The results of warming cannot be compared with those of cooling. (D) The results of warming cannot be compared with those of cooling

context: Australia is a large and sparsely populated country, where labor is expensive and it is difficult to find workers, which worries many ranchers. One rancher, Del, has an idea. explanation: A lot of electricity is wasted,“ explains Yu

context: Regret aversion“ means that when people take the initiative to make irrational, unconventional or non-traditional decisions, the wrong result will make them regret the behavior. Loss aversion refers to the fact that when people face gains and losses of the same value, they find the loss more unbearable
question: According to the above conclusion, which of the following belong to regret and aversion
A: Xiao Li is used to driving to and from work. When she got off work yesterday, she was arranged by her boss to drive an important customer home. There was an accident on the way.
B: Zhang Guan lost a pen worth 20 yuan and then found 20 yuan in cash on the road. He was still unhappy all day and regretted it. “I should have paid attention to where the pen was.“
C: Mr. Bi chose several stocks with a small number of investors to invest in. As a result, all of these stocks fell by the daily limit. Mr. Bi regretted, “If I had known I would not have bought these stocks.“
D: Liu Chang was influenced by another hiker and was forced to choose a road that he did not usually take. As a result, both of them were hurt in danger. Liu Chang regretted that; “If I had known, I would not have taken this road.“
explanation: Regret and aversion: (1) take the initiative to make irrational, unconventional or unconventional decisions: (2) the wrong result makes you feel disgusted with your actions. Loss aversion: ① in the face of the same value of acceptance and approval ② think the loss and endure.

context: Pediatric neurodermatitis has long been thought to be caused by an allergy to breast milk. But if we take children off breast milk and switch them to cow's milk, their neurodermatitis doesn't go away. So clearly there is something else that causes neurodermatitis in children.
question: Which of the following, if true, best supports the conclusion of the stem

B: Medical science has not yet revealed the pathological mechanism of neurodermatitis induced by breast milk allergy in children.
C: Medical science has not yet revealed the pathological mechanism of neurodermatitis induced by breast milk allergy in children.
D: Medical science has not yet revealed the pathological mechanism of neurodermatitis induced by breast milk allergy in children.
explanation: explanation: If the children stop eating breast milk and switch to cow milk, their neurodermatitis will not disappear. Then it can be proved that there is some other reason (other than breast milk) causing pediatric neurodermatitis. A, breast milk is the most ideal food for infants, does not mean that it does not cause neurodermatitis in children, cannot be supported. B) There is no evidence to support or refute it. C) to prove that children who have never eaten breast milk can get neurodermatitis. C) to prove that breast milk does not cause neurodermatitis. D) It is not the same disease as the mother's breast milk

context: “For people who want to get fit, alternating multiple workouts is better than a single workout. A few muscles develop with a single exercise, while the overall muscle group develops with multiple exercises, which burn more calories than the former.
question: If which of the following statements is true, it most strongly strengthens the argument above?
A: In healthy people, health gains in direct proportion to calorie consumption.
B: Exercise training is the most effective way to keep fit.
C: It is much more difficult to develop all the muscle groups of the human body than to promote the development of a few muscles.
D: D: Physical exercise is more important than diet for bodybuilders
explanation: From the explanation, more calories are consumed by alternating multiple physical exercises, and it is concluded that alternating multiple physical exercises is better than a single exercise.

context: When the chemical agent VIANZONE is added to any clear solution containing sodium chloride, the solution will become cloudy; When the chemical VIANZONE is added to a clear solution containing potassium nitrate, the solution will become cloudy; But the chemical VIANZONE did not change the solution containing benzene. In one experiment, the chemical VIANZONE was added to a clear solution and the solution remained clear
question: According to the above experiment, which of the following can be inferred to be true
A: The clear solution contains potassium nitrate
B: The clear solution contains sodium chloride and benzene
C: The clear solution does not contain benzene
D: Clear solution does not contain sodium chloride
explanation: From “the chemical agent VIANZONE is added to a transparent solution and the solution remains transparent“, we can see that the solution does not become cloudy, which negates the latter part of the two sufficiently conditional hypothetical propositions. Therefore, we can deduce the negative antecedents: the transparent solution does not contain sodium chloride and the transparent solution does not contain potassium nitrate. A and B are false and D are true. (C) Because the chemical VIANZONE does not change a solution containing benzene, we do not know whether the solution contains benzene. (D) The solution contains benzene

context: “The scientists found that the levels of a protein called SK3 in the brains of mice at different ages correlated closely with their ability to remember things: older mice had higher levels of SK3, younger mice had less; And the older mice had worse memory than the younger ones. Therefore, scientists believe that increased levels of the SK3 protein in the brain caused memory loss in the mice
question: Which of the following, if true, best supports the scientists' conclusion
A: High levels of the SK3 protein in the brain were also found in young laboratory mice.
B: It has been found that the human brain also contains SK3 protein.
C: When scientists managed to reduce the amount of SK3 protein in the brains of older mice, their memory improved
D: D: Scientists have figured out the molecular structure of the SK3 protein
explanation: Scientists have found that increased levels of SK3 protein in the brain may cause memory decline in laboratory mice.“ The memory of the experimental mice will be improved after the SK3 protein content in the brain is reduced, which further explains the effect of SK3 protein content in the brain on the memory of the experimental mice, which supports the explanation of the question.

context: “In Chinese history, officials were generally given a low salary so that the emperor could control them. Because when the salary is low, the official is bound to be corrupt. However, if item C is assumed by the question, then it is obvious that a conclusion can be drawn. C must be assumed by the question

context: To protect the natural environment, it is necessary to build a good environmental protection system. context: It is widely accepted that moderate physical activity can reduce stroke risk, but scientists have also noted that some chemicals can reduce stroke risk. Lycopene is the chemical that gives fruits and vegetables such as tomatoes, peppers, watermelon and papaya their red color. Researchers followed more than 1,000 people aged 46 to 55 for 12 years and found that 11 of those in the quarter with the highest lycopene levels had strokes, while 25 of those in the lowest quarter had strokes. They concluded that lycopene could reduce the risk of stroke
question: Which of the following, if true, calls into question the findings above?
A: 50 of the subjects had strokes.
B: If you look at people between the ages of 56 and 65, the situation may be different.
C: About a quarter of people with high lycopene levels enjoy moderate physical activity.
D: Smoking, high blood pressure and diabetes can cause stroke.
explanation: Study conclusion: Lycopene can reduce the incidence of stroke. In the other half of the population, 50 people with moderate lycopene levels had a stroke, and this 50 percent had the same rate of stroke as the 25 percent with the lowest lycopene levels, suggesting that the increase in lycopene levels did not reduce the risk of stroke in the three quarters of the population.

context: A seemingly contradictory phenomenon exists in the industry of country R: on the one hand, according to the law of the country, workers cannot be fired for life, and the wage scale can only go up but not down; On the other hand, this has not prevented factory owners from introducing advanced production equipment, which has increased labor productivity, leaving some workers virtually idle (for example, jobs that could be performed by three or two thousand people).
question: Which of the following related claims, if true, most reasonably explains the above phenomenon
A: The profit created by the increase in labor productivity by advanced equipment exceeds the expense of retraining workers for other jobs.
B: The introduction of advanced equipment has raised the final cost of the product
C: R country is under pressure to amend the said law.
D: The products of Country R are highly competitive in the world
explanation: The seemingly paradoxical phenomenon existing in the industry of country R is that some workers are actually idle because of advanced production equipment.

context: In the 2000 census conducted in Country H, marital status was divided into four categories: unmarried, married, divorced, and widowed. Among them, married was classified as normal marriage and separated; Separation is divided into legal separation and illegal separation; Illegal separation refers to illegal cohabitation between the separated person and others; Illegal cohabitation refers to cohabitation between people of the opposite sex who are not married. According to the census, there are one million more women than men living apart illegally.
question: If the above statement and the corresponding data are true, and the above illegal cohabitants are all citizens of Country H, which of the following statement concerning Country H must be true?
A: Only Ⅱ. ⅱ. More men than women live illegally with a separated person.
B: only Ⅲ. ⅲ. There are more males than females among the separated persons who are living illegally with the separated person.
C: Only Ⅰ and Ⅱ. ⅰ. There are more men than women among unmarried, divorced or widowed persons living illegally with a separated person. ⅱ. There are more men than women living illegally with a separated person.
D: Ⅰ, Ⅱ and Ⅲ. ⅰ. There are more males than females among unmarried, divorced or widowed persons living illegally with a separated person. ⅱ. There are more men than women living with a separated person illegally. ⅲ. There are more men than women living illegally with a separated person.
explanation: There are two types of illegal cohabitation with the separated person: cohabitation between the separated person and the separated person; The separated person cohabitates with a person who is not married (unmarried, divorced or widowed). (1) Illegal cohabitation refers to cohabitation between members of the opposite sex. Therefore, the number of separated persons living illegally with the separated person is equal to that of men and women. (3) Check number Ⅲ is false. The number of unmarried, divorced, or widowed people living with a separated person is 1 million more than that of men. So check I is true. ③ Persons who are living illegally with a separated person include two parts, one is a separated person and the other is unmarried, divorced or widowed. Two conclusions have been drawn above: first, the number of separated persons living illegally with a separated person is equal to that of men and women; Secondly, there are more men than women among unmarried, divorced or widowed persons living illegally with a separated person. Therefore, it can be concluded that there are more men than women living illegally with a separated person. So check Ⅱ is true.

context: “The scholar Zhang said:“ The problem itself is not mysterious, cause and effect is not only a matter for philosophers. context: Many people not only do not understand others, but also do not understand themselves, and though they may have tried to understand others, such an effort is doomed to failure, for he who does not understand himself cannot understand others. context: Lead and paving are two heavy metals emitted from cigarette smoke. context: 1 There were 90 patients, all suffering from disease T, and all had taken the same conventional medication. context: A group of British doctors announced that they were starting to treat Apple iPad users for a condition similar to repetitive strain injury, nicknamed 'I-injury', in which users develop various aches and pains in their hands and fingers when they click and touch the screen. D provides some support, but less so than A.

context: Today, electronic learning machines have fully entered the lives of children. question: Which of the following, if true, best supports the expert's view?

explanation: Enhanced title. The e - learning machine may not be conducive to the child's growth. The author concludes that parents should spare some time to accompany their children to read paper books and promote their children's spiritual growth in communication. Argument: Parents accompany their children to read paper books is beneficial to children's growth. Conclusion: Electronic learning machines may not be good for children's development. Second, electronic learning machine makes it difficult for parents to accompany their children to read, which is not conducive to the communication between parents and children, and is not conducive to the growth of children. That is to say, we should accompany our children to read this paper book to increase communication and promote growth, which can best support the expert's opinion.

context: Researchers analyzed medical records of nearly 4,000 Asian and non-Asian cancer patients in Southern California. explanation: The explanation explains that due to biological differences, the tumors in Asians are less invasive, so the survival rate of Asians is much higher than that of patients of other races.

explanation: Explanation “:“ Argument: Immunoglobulin E triggers an allergic reaction that prevents the damaged cells from transforming into tumor cells. Conclusion: People prone to skin allergies are at a lower risk of skin cancer.

context: In the 2015 census conducted in Country H, marital status was divided into four categories: unmarried, married, divorced and widowed. Among them, married is classified as normal marriage and separated; Separation is divided into legal separation and illegal separation; Illegal separation refers to illegal cohabitation between the separated person and others; Illegal cohabitation refers to cohabitation between people of the opposite sex who are not married. According to the census, there are one million more women than men living apart illegally.
question: If the above statement and the corresponding data are true, and the above illegal cohabitants are all citizens of Country H, which of the following statement concerning Country H must be true?
A: Only I. Ⅰ. There are more men than women who are unmarried, divorced or widowed living illegally with a separated person.
B: Only Ⅱ. Ⅱ. More men than women live illegally with a separated person.
C: Only Ⅲ. Ⅲ. More men than women live with the separated illegally.
D: Only Ⅰ and Ⅱ. Ⅰ. There are more men than women who are unmarried, divorced or widowed living illegally with a separated person. Ⅱ. More men than women live illegally with a separated person.
explanation: Illegal cohabitation with the separated person includes two types: cohabitation between the separated person and the separated person; The separated person cohabitates with a person who is not married (unmarried, divorced or widowed). From the subject, illegal cohabitation refers to cohabitation between members of the opposite sex, so the number of separated persons living illegally with the separated person is 50/50 for men and 50/50 for women. So check number Ⅲ is false. There are one million more women than men living with a separated person illegally, which means that there are more men than women who are unmarried, divorced or widowed living with a separated person. So check I is true. A person who is living illegally with a separated person includes two parts: one is a separated person and the other is unmarried, divorced or widowed. Two conclusions have been drawn from the above: first, the number of separated persons living illegally with a separated person is equal to that of men and women; Secondly, there are more men than women among unmarried, divorced or widowed persons living illegally with a separated person. Therefore, it can be concluded that there are more men than women living illegally with a separated person. So check Ⅱ is true.

context: A thermo-optical generator is a device that can efficiently convert heat energy into electrical energy. Conclusion: If the heat wasted by the thermo-optical generator can be converted into electricity in the production process, the production cost of the steel works can be greatly reduced.

context: At a party, five out of ten people who ate a fruit salad quickly became visibly ill. The leftover salad was immediately sent for testing. context: The remains of animals and plants that grew in or near water are the most easily preserved, because the necessary condition for their preservation is quick burial. In oceans, rivers, and lakes where silt accumulates, the remains of animals, plants, and other things can be buried quickly.

Therefore, the conclusion should be that remains of animals and plants are readily preserved in oceans, rivers, and even lakes where silt is continuously deposited.

context: If all birds can fly, and penguins are birds, then penguins can fly.
question: From this premise which of the following premises needs to be added in order to logically follow the conclusion that “some birds cannot fly
A: Some birds can fly, and penguins are birds.
B: Penguins can't fly, and penguins are birds.
C: Penguins can't fly, but all birds can fly.
D: Penguins can't fly, and penguins are not birds.
explanation: “Explanation“, “the premise: all birds can fly studying penguins are birds ⇒ penguins can fly. Conclusion: some birds can't fly. Step 2: Derive from the information in the question stem. Premise “all the birds can fly studying penguins are birds ⇒ penguins can fly“ is a hypothetical proposition, before a “all the birds can fly studying penguins are birds,“ is a proposition league said, after a “penguins can fly; Conclusion before “some birds can't fly“ is the premise of the proposition “all birds can fly. To negate one of the preceding propositions, one must first negate the preceding proposition. According to the rule of inverse negation, the latter can be derived from the former. It can be seen that to negate “all birds can fly“, one must first negate “penguins can fly“, that is, to guarantee “-penguins can fly“. According to the rules of topsy-turvy, “- penguins can fly ⇒ - (all birds can fly studying penguins are birds)“, according to the rules of Morgan, “- (all birds can fly a penguin is a bird)“ is equivalent to a “- all birds can fly ∪ - penguins are birds“, namely “or some birds can't fly, or a penguin is not bird“. “Or some birds can't fly, or a penguin is not bird“ is disjunctive proposition, to get some birds can't fly, or need to deny another proposition “penguin is not a bird“, namely the guarantee “penguin is a bird. In conclusion, to reach the conclusion that “some birds can't fly“, it is necessary to add the prerequisite that “penguins can't fly, and penguins are birds“

explanation: Explains both arguments. Mr. Chen: Premise: Bees transmit information by scent. Conclusion: Bees do not communicate by buzzing. Ms Jia: The transmission of information by bees through scent traces is only one way of communication, not the only way of communication. That is to say, there is a possibility of the transmission of information through mouth sounds. The analysis of the structure of the two shows that the difference between them lies in whether the premises leading to the same conclusion are the same. So the debate between the two is whether or not the bee communicates by what metaphorical sounds it makes.

context: Those who row harder are the first: those who fight in the middle win. On our new journey, we are faced with both rare opportunities and severe challenges. context: “Sharks are generally carnivorous, but some scientists say they found a narrow-headed hammerhead shark in one area that eats plants as an important part of its diet.
question: The following, if true, best support the scientists' findin

B: narrow-headed hammerhead sharks artificially fed a special diet consisting of 90% seaweed gained weight over a 3-week perio
C: The gut of the narrow-headed hammerhead shark was found to contain an enzyme that efficiently decomposes plants, which is not present in the gut of other shark
D: The blood of the narrow-headed hammerhead shark contains large amounts of a certain nutrient that is not made naturally and is only found in small amounts in seaweed
explanation: Step one: Identify the arguments and arguments. Argument: The narrow-headed hammerhead shark uses plants as an important part of its diet. Argument: None. A topic has only an argument, so it can only be strengthened by providing additional evidence (e.g. explaining why and giving examples). Step 2: Analyze the options one by one. A: Plants were found in the stomach of some narrow-headed hammerhead sharks, and half of the shark's diet consists of plants, indicating that the shark feeds on plants, strengthening and retaining by way of example; B: The body weight of narrow-headed hammerhead sharks increased when the diet with a large proportion of seaweed was fed, but this does not mean that this shark takes plants as the main food, which is unrelated, cannot be strengthened and excluded; C: This means that the body of the narrow-headed hammerhead shark has the enzyme to digest plants, but the presence of the enzyme does not mean that the narrow-headed hammerhead shark will eat plants or will use this enzyme, unrelated, cannot strengthen, excluded; D: This shark has a large amount of a nutrient that cannot be produced by itself, and only a small amount of this nutrient is found in seaweed in nature, indicating that the nutrients in the body of the narrow-headed hammerhead shark come from a large amount of seaweed, which means that the seaweed is an important part of the diet of the narrow-headed hammerhead shark, and this item is strengthened and retained by explaining the reason. In contrast to AD, where A is an example and D is an explanation, D is stronger than A.

context: Nobody loves everybody; The cowherd loves the weaver; The Weaver loves everyone who loves the Cowherd.

explanation: If Ⅰ is true, then combining with“ Zhi Nu loves everyone who loves Niu Lang “, we know that “Zhi Nu loves everyone“, which cannot be true at the same time as “no one loves everyone“, therefore, Ⅰ cannot be true. “No one loves everyone“ is equivalent to “everyone will not love everyone“. If everyone loves only a part of the people, it also follows that everyone will not love all people, so Ⅱ may be true. “Cowherd love Weaver“, “love“ is a semi-symmetric relationship, then the weaver may love Cowherd, may not love Cowherd. context: Dad: Got a girlfriend at school? Son: No. Dad: Why didn't you bring it back? Son: I left it at school. Dad: It's not your girlfriend playing, is it? Son: Nonsense. She has her own

context: From AD 250 to 800, the Mayan civilization was still very advanced, with prosperous cities and good crops. explanation: Cause: Climate changes of the century (precipitation decreases, climate becomes arid). → Answer: Mayan civilization is extinct. It means that drought led to the demise of the Maya civilization

context: The trial found that appropriate vitamin D supplementation in pregnant women reduced the risk of respiratory syncytial virus infection in newborns. Conclusions: “Appropriate supplementation of vitamin D in pregnant women can reduce the risk of respiratory syncytial virus infection in newborns“. Vitamin D has a variety of disease-prevention and health functions, including improving the function of the immune system, promoting the development of the respiratory system of newborns, preventing respiratory virus infection of newborns, etc. “That is to say, vitamin D also has the role of preventing respiratory virus infection of newborns, thus strengthening the scientific findings in the question

context: One study found that bears that regularly consumed human food had significantly shorter hibernation periods, up to 50 days, and that these bears had significantly fewer telomeres than bears that maintained a natural diet. Step 2: Examine the options one by one. A) The length of telomeres in cancer cells is the length of telomeres in cancer cells. A) The length of telomeres is the length of telomeres in cancer cells. explanation: Explanation“ for azimuth relations. From condition 1, we know that the chrysanthemum is on the far left; And from condition 4 we know that the leftmost flower is yellow. The white rose is in the middle.

context: In order to predict the employment intention of college students after graduation, Employment Guide magazine conducted a questionnaire survey among college students, and the results showed that more than half of the respondents chose teaching as their first choice. context: In one study, 51 middle school student volunteers were divided into a test group and a control group for the same math ability training. context: In product inspection, false detection includes two cases: one is to define unqualified products as qualified; The other is to define the unqualified product as unqualified. There are two product inspection systems, A and B, which are based on different principles, but have something in common: first, they can detect all the unqualified products sent for inspection; Secondly, they both have a false detection rate of exactly 3%; And third, there is no product that can be misdetected by both systems. The two systems are now combined into one system so that products determined to be nonconforming by the system include and only include products determined to be nonconforming by both systems when operating Ⅰ separately. It can be concluded that the false detection rate of such a product inspection system is zero.
question: Which of the following most appropriately evaluates the reasoning above?
A: The above reasoning is necessary, that is, if the premises are true, then the conclusion must be true.
B: The above reasoning is strong but not necessary, that is, if the premises are true, strong evidence is provided for the conclusion, but the additional information is still acceptable
C: The above reasoning is weak, and the premises, though relevant to the conclusion, at best provide only inadequate grounds for the conclusion.
D: This reasoning fails because it takes the ground of necessary conditions for the occurrence of an event as the ground of sufficient conditions.
explanation: According to the explanation, there are only two kinds of misdetection, and both system A and System B can detect all unqualified products. Therefore, if there is misdetection in system A and System B, qualified products can only be classified as unqualified. According to the explanation, there is 3% false detection rate in both system A and System B, so system A and system B will define part of qualified products as unqualified. The false detection rate of the new system formed by the combination of the two systems is zero. According to the question, “There is no one product, which will be mistakenly detected by both systems“. So as long as the premises are true, the conclusion must be true.

context: The people are both creators and witnesses of history; They are not only “players“ in history, but also “playwriters“ of history. B: The makers of history are not actors in history

context: In the 19th century, the Institut des Arts Francaise was the main patron of French painting and sculpture, at a time when individual sponsors had declined dramatically. question: Which of the following, if true, best explains the difference in innovation between 19th-century French painting and sculpture?

B: In the 19th century, sculptors received more financial support from the French Academy of Arts than painters
C: There were more unsponsored paintings than unsponsored sculptures in 19th century France, as paints and canvases were cheaper than the stone used for sculpture.
D: Very few French artists in the 19th century painted as well as sculpted
explanation: The main sponsoring departments for French painting and sculpture are the French Arts Institute, which does not encourage artistic innovation. It is only necessary to find the difference factors that cause the different results between sculpture and painting. C) Painting did not depend on the patronage of the French Academy of Arts as sculpture did. A) Since painting is getting more money from the French arts Institute, why not listen to them and not innovate? B) Painters received less money because they needed less money. It is possible that most of the artists' work was sponsored by the French Academy of Arts. D) The artists received less money

context: Many scientists act professionally only to improve their professional ability, to do better, to improve their personal situation, and the pursuit of truth takes a back seat. Therefore, the behavior of the community of scientists is also to improve the situation of the community, which, purely by accident, seeks the truth.
question: Which of the following most accurately points out the fallacy in the argument above?
A: The argument is suspected of degrading the moral character of the scientist.
B: From the fact that many scientists have a certain quality, it unreasonably follows that the community of scientists also has that quality.
C: It is unreasonably assumed that the improvement of one's professional competence will not increase the efficiency of the co-discovery of truth.
D: From the fact that most scientists have a certain quality, it is unreasonable to infer that every scientist has that quality.
explanation: Many scientists' professional behaviors are simply aimed at improving their professional abilities, achieving better results, and improving their personal situation, with the pursuit of truth taking a back seat. Argument: The behavior of the community of scientists is also to improve the situation of the community, and it is purely by chance that the community will pursue the truth. In conclusion, the community of scientists refers to the whole community of scientists. Therefore, judging the situation of the whole community of scientists according to the situation of many scientists is a mistake of synthesis, that is, believing that the nature of the parts is also the same as that of the whole

context: Kobayashi was denied entry to the deep pool because he was not wearing a swimming cap. Kobayashi shows the deep water certificate and says: According to the regulations, I can enter the deep pool. The rules of the swimming pool are: no one can enter the pool without a swimming cap; Only those with a deep water certificate can enter the deep pool.
question: Kobayashi is most likely to interpret the swimming pool regulations
A: You are not allowed to enter a deep pool unless you have a deep water certificate.
B: Swimming caps are not required only for holders of deep water certificate.
C: If you hold the deep water certificate, you can enter the deep pool.
D: With a deep water certificate, there is no need to wear a swimming cap.
explanation: First step, summarize the conditions for the explanation. The regulations of the swimming pool: only holders of deep-water qualification certificate can enter the deep pool. Xiao Lin: I have a deep water certificate. According to the regulations, I can enter the deep pool. The second step is to analyze the answer. According to the regulations of the swimming pool, holding a deep water certificate is a necessary condition to be allowed to enter the deep pool. Kobayashi apparently misinterpreted this rule to mean that having a certificate of qualification for deep water is a sufficient condition for entry into the deep pool

context: The same number of cucumber seedlings were planted in the two experimental greenhouses. Magnesium salt was added in the first greenhouse but not in the second. The first produced 10 kilograms of cucumbers and the second produced 5 kilograms. Since nothing but water was applied to the greenhouses, the higher yield in the first greenhouse must have been due to the magnesium salt.
question: Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument above:
A: There is a small amount of magnesium salt in the soil of both experimental greenhouses
B: In the third experiment greenhouse, a high-nitrogen fertilizer was applied without magnesium salt, and 7 kilograms of cucumbers were produced
C: Four different cucumber varieties were grown in both greenhouses
D: The soil quality and sunlight amount in the two test greenhouses were different
explanation: Step 1: Analyze the explanation and find the arguments and arguments. The conclusion of this question is that “the higher yield in the first greenhouse must be due to magnesium salt“, provided that “the same number of cucumber seedlings were planted in the two experimental greenhouses, magnesium salt was added in the first greenhouse but not in the second greenhouse, 10 kg of cucumbers were produced in the first greenhouse and 5 kg in the second greenhouse, and nothing else was applied to the greenhouses except water“. All other conditions should be the same for two types of objects. The only difference is that one is added with magnesium salt and the other is not. The results of the experiment are compared. Step 2: Analyze the choices one by one. A: There is a small amount of magnesium salt in the soil, which is the same condition of the two experiment greenhouses, which is not directly related to the application of magnesium salt or not. B: The third experiment greenhouse applied a kind of high nitrogen fertilizer but did not add magnesium salt, which produced 7 kilograms of cucumbers. The application of nitrogen fertilizer is not directly related to the application of magnesium salt or not, which is irrelevant. C: Four different cucumber varieties were planted, the species of which were not directly related to the application of magnesium salt or not, and were independent options; D: The soil quality and sunshine amount of the two greenhouses were different, indicating that magnesium salt was not the only factor, but other factors were also different, thus undermining the conclusion

context: “Numerous studies have shown that running is good for your health, and recently according to US Health News, too much running can shorten your life span. context: In the past three years, the annual profit of catering industry in Beijing and Tianjin has been stable at about 80 million yuan. context: There are more than 30 billion brain cells in the human body, only a fraction of which are involved in normal intellectual activity. Two conditions are necessary for the effective development of the intelligence of young people. First, they must be kept thinking so that more brain cells can be activated; Second, they must be given enough of the nutrients needed for the growth of brain cells so that they can divide properly. “125 brain stimulin“ has a variety of nutrients needed for adolescent brain development. According to a nationwide survey of about 10,000 teenagers who took the supplement, 125 has an undisputed role in promoting healthy brain development and subsequently developing their intelligence
question: If the above assertion is true, which of the following inferences about a group of schoolchildren is true
A: Only I. ⅰ. Zhang Quan is diligent in thinking and has taken enough 125 brain hormone. Therefore, his intelligence must be effectively developed.
B: Only Ⅱ. ⅱ. Li Lu's intelligence has been effectively developed but she has not taken 125 brain supplements. Therefore, she must be hard to think.
C: Ⅱ and Ⅲ. ⅱ. Li Lu's intelligence has been effectively developed but she has not taken 125 brain supplements, so she must be too busy thinking. ⅲ. Wang Qiong is diligent in thinking but her intelligence has not been effectively developed. Therefore, she must not have taken in enough nutrients needed for the growth of brain cells.
D: Ⅰ, Ⅱ and Ⅲ. ⅰ. Zhang Quan is diligent in thinking and takes sufficient amount of “125 brain“, so his intelligence must be effectively developed. ⅱ. Li Lu's intelligence has been effectively developed but she has not taken 125 brain, therefore, she must be restricted to thinking. ⅲ. Wang Qiong is diligent in thinking but her intelligence has not been effectively developed. Therefore, she must not have taken in enough nutrients needed for the growth of brain cells.
explanation: ① To effectively develop the intelligence of teenagers → teenagers must think diligently; teenagers must take in enough nutrients; ② “125 brain hormone“ can provide enough nutrients and promote adolescent brain development. Inference I mistake necessary conditions for sufficient conditions, thinking diligently and taking in sufficient nutrients are only necessary conditions for the effective development of adolescent intelligence, but not sufficient conditions. Therefore, inference-ⅰ is not valid. Inference Ⅱ is valid, because according to condition ① and the premise of inference Ⅱ, Li Lu must have been thinking diligently and ingested enough nutrients “125 brain hormone“ is the source of sufficient nutrients, but not the only source. Similar to inference, inference Ⅲ is also not valid. Inferences Ⅲ mistake necessary conditions for sufficient conditions. The underdevelopment of intelligence may not necessarily be due to insufficient intake of the nutrients that brain cells need to grow, but there may be other reasons.

context: Doctors A, B, C and D shall be on duty from Monday to Thursday, each on duty for only one day, and only one person on duty each day. context: A new treatment for a disease resulted in significant improvement in 68% of patients in a 12-month clinical trial, 43% of whom were cured. context: “An English reformer in the nineteenth century said that every industrious farmer owned at least two cows. Those farmers who do not own cattle are usually lazy people. question: The reformer clearly makes a logical error. Which of the following is similar to the error?

explanation: The reformer thinks that the farmer's lack of cattle leads to being lazy and eating. In fact, being lazy and eating is the reason for the lack of cattle. The reformer makes the logical error of inverted cause and effect.

context: Left-handed people are more likely than right-handed people to suffer from certain immune disorders, such as allergies. However, lefties also have advantages over right-handed people. explanation: ① I can't be explained from the explanation, because from “left-handed people are more likely to suffer from certain immune disorders than right-handed people“, we can't deduce that “more left-handers than right-handers suffer from immune disorders“. For example, from “Miao girls are better at dancing than Han girls“, it cannot be deduced that “Among those who are better at dancing, Miao girls are more than Han girls“. ②Ⅱ can not be derived from the question, because the question does not determine the proportion of people who are strong or weak in mathematical reasoning. ③Ⅲ can be deduced from the question stem. context: Some researchers believe that human hair loss is caused by nutritional imbalance. However, there are opponents who believe that hair loss is caused by damage to the hair follicles. question: Which of the following, if true, most weakens the opponent's argument?

B: People who live under nutrition for a long time tend to have yellow hair and hair loss.
C: Damaged hair follicles prevent them from absorbing nutrients from the scalp, resulting in hair loss.
D: Hair loss is becoming more and more prevalent among young people and has become a lingering problem for many.
explanation: The researchers' view: Nutritional imbalance (cause) → hair loss (effect). Can be seen as: X, Y. Naysayers' view: Hair follicle damage (cause) → hair loss (effect). Thought of as: Z one →Y. When nerfing, consider the cleavage relationship to be the strongest. In this case, to weaken the researcher's opinion, a relationship can be constructed: Z one +X→Y proves that Z is the root cause of Y, thus splitting the relationship between X and Y. To weaken the arguments of opponents, a relationship can be constructed: X→Z→Y proves that X is the root cause of Y, thus splitting the relationship between Z and Y

context: An advertisement for a new type of aircraft engine states: tests have shown that it is significantly safer than older model engines, with only slightly higher fuel consumption. explanation: The advertisement for the new aircraft engine claims that the new model is safer than the old one; In fact, the new model does not sell as well as the old one. context: Parent of student: The student's vision is generally declining this semester due to the heavy burden of the student's written work. context: If the implementation of the above principles can have different binding on the social behavior of officials and civilians.
question: None of the following statements violate this principle, except
A: A permitted or prohibited act is not necessarily expressly permitted or prohibited by statute.
B: Some acts are permitted to be performed by officials but forbidden to be performed by civilians.
C: An act performed by an official is permitted to be performed by a civilian if the statute expressly permits it.
D: An act performed by an official which, if expressly prohibited by statute, is prohibited by a civilian.
explanation: Acts that are neither allowed nor forbidden by regulations are permitted by civilians but forbidden by officials. If an act is allowed to be carried out by an official, it must be an act permitted by law; And an act permitted by law cannot be prohibited from being carried out by civilians. Every act expressly permitted by law is permitted by a civilian. Whatever is expressly forbidden by the statute, is forbidden by the plebes.

context: There is a new type of computer keyboard on the market. The new keyboard has the “best of three“ features that traditional keyboards do not have. context: In social life, people are often faced with a choice. They can either choose an opportunity with low risk and low reward. Or an opportunity with higher risk and higher reward. B and D has nothing to do for option C have weaken the meaning of, only have A certain strengthen effect, can only choose A.

context: Urban pollution is a prominent problem in industrialized society. Urban residents generally suffer from higher rates of pollution than rural residents. But strangely enough, trees in urban centers actually grow thicker and bigger than those in the countryside.

context: There are four children in the family. They are A, B, C and D. One day, a few candies were missing on the dinner table. Their mother asked who had stolen the candies. The four children had different stories. The other said, None of us ate the candy; C said: At least one of us didn't steal the candy. Ding said: I didn't steal the candy.
question: If two of the four children are telling the truth and two are lying, the one who is telling the truth
A: A and C are the truth tellers
B: A and D who speak the truth
C: C: Those who tell the truth are B and
D: Those who speak the truth are B and
explanation: Step 1: Analyze the explanation. A: Some have stolen it; B: None of them; C: B did not steal or D did not steal; Ding: Ding didn't steal it. By comparison, it can be found that there is a contradiction between A and B, there must be one true and one false, so it can be inferred that there must be one true and one false between Bingding and Ding. If D's statement is true, then C's statement must also be true. Therefore, D's statement must be false, and C's statement must be true. That is, D stole, but B did not. Since D stole the candy, it can be inferred that someone else stole the candy, so what A said must also be true. Therefore, it is A and C who tell the truth.

B: If a man can make continuous progress, he can accomplish nothing
C: can make continuous progress, or can listen to objective evaluation.
D: Either to make continuous progress or to listen to objective evaluation.
explanation: ① Progress → a correct understanding of oneself. ② Continuous progress V leads nowhere. ③ Cannot listen to objective evaluation → cannot understand oneself correctly. Combined with ①, ② and ③, we can deduce: ④ will not accomplish nothing → continuous progress → correct understanding of oneself -- Listen to objective evaluation. A: The Q position in condition ④ is confirmed. The information cannot be determined to be true. B: Option 4 affirms bit Q of condition ④ and cannot give information that is determined to be true. C: Choice = inability to make continuous progress → ability to listen to objective evaluation, which negates position P in condition ④, which cannot be ascertained to be true information. D: Choice is consistent with the reasoning of condition ④ and must be true

context: A scientist recently proposed that the Earth's plate movements began no later than 3.5 billion years ago. His reasoning is that plate movement must have changed nature's dark mafic rocks into light felsic rocks. And by 3.5 billion years ago, we already had light felsic rocks.
question: The following, if true, most strongly question the expert's opini
A: The light-colored felsic rocks are essentially“ regenerated “from the dark-colored mafic rocks that dominated the Earth in absolute numbers billions of years ago
B: Analysis of 3.5 billion-year-old sediment samples from around the globe shows that less than half of these contain felsic rock particles
C: The only explanation for the much greater proportion of felsic rocks in nature than mafic rocks seems to be plate tectonics, but early plate tectonics was likely to have been sporadic and localized
D: Three and a half billion years ago, the Earth was full of volcanoes. The magma released by the eruptions buried the mafic rocks deep underground. The mafic rocks were melted and transformed into alsic rocks, but plate movement was not the only cause of volcanic eruption
explanation: Step one: Identify the arguments and arguments. Argument: The Earth's plate movements began no later than 3.5 billion years ago. The argument: Plate movement must have changed nature's dark mafic rocks into light felsic rocks, which were already present 3.5 billion years ago. Step 2: Analyze the options one by one. A: It is possible to tell when the Earth's plate movements began by the presence of light felsic rocks. The quantity of ferric and mafic rocks is different, and billions of years of time is not clear enough to reduce or eliminate. B: It is possible to date the beginning of plate movement by the presence of light felsic rocks. It is possible to determine the proportion of particles of felsic rocks in the sedimentary layer. C, “it seems“ and “probably“ mean that it is not certain whether the plate movement caused the transformation of mafic rocks into felsic rocks, or whether the plate movement directly caused the high proportion of felsic rocks, and it does not mention the time, it is not clear, can not be weakened, excluded; D) Volcanic eruptions can transform mafic rocks into felsic rocks, but plate motion is not the only cause of volcanic eruptions. The transformation of mafic rocks into felsic rocks is not necessarily related to plate motion

context: According to the statistics of the United Nations Development Programme in 2007, Norway is the country with the highest quality of life in the world, and developed countries such as Europe, the United States and Japan are also among the best. If you look at the countries where the quality of life has improved the most since 1990, the developed world lags behind. At least among the 116 countries counted by the United Nations Development Programme, the southeast African country of Mozambique has seen the fastest improvement in quality of life over the past 17 years, with its quality of life index rising 50 percent in 2007 from 1990. Many African countries have made similar gains. As one of the most prominent developing countries in the world, China's quality of Life index has also increased by 27 percent over the past 17 years.
question: Which of the following can be derived from UNDP statistics?
A: In 2007, the quality of life index of developing countries was lower than that of western countries
B: In 2007, Mozambique's quality of life index was no higher than China's
C: In 2006, Mozambique's quality of life improved faster than any other country in Africa
D: D: Norway had a higher quality of life index than Africa in 2007
explanation: Analyzes the information about the title. In 2007, Norway had the highest quality of life in the world, higher than other countries, including those in Africa

context: Mineral exploration personnel have observed that although mineral crystals of different colors and shapes have different names and representations, they may be the same chemical composition of substances crystallized into crystals of different structures under different physical and chemical conditions, and generally have different physical characteristics. Therefore, different mineral species may have the same chemical composition.
question: Which of the following strengthens the argument above
A: Carbon trioxide and dry ice have different names and different appearances.
B: Mineral crystals of different colors change color when exposed to air.
C: Analytical instruments can quickly determine the chemical composition of mineral crystals.
D: Silicon dioxide can have 12 different mineral crystals.
explanation: The explanation“ is that different mineral species can have the same chemical composition. Silica can have 12 different mineral crystals, which means that there are 12 different mineral crystals that can be composed of silica, so this strengthens the argument.

context: A football coach instructs his players,“ In football, the hero is always the result. In football, you either win or lose; In the eyes of the fans, you are either brave or weak. Since all winners are brave in the eyes of the fans, every loser is a wimp in the eyes of the fans.“
question: Which of the following must be assumed in order for the football coach's argument above to hold?
A: In the eyes of the fans, the brave man wins on the pitch.
B: Football fans have the right judgment to distinguish the brave from the cowardly.
C: Even on the field, winning or losing is not the only thing that separates bravery from cowardice
D: In football, the winner must be the brave man.
explanation: First, summarize the conditions of the problem. (1) In a football match, one winner → the loser. (2) In the eyes of football fans, it is either the brave or the cowardly. (3) In the eyes of fans, the winner → the brave. Conclusion: In the eyes of fans, losers → wimps. In the second step, the answer is analyzed. ① If, in the eyes of the fans, the winners are all brave, but not all brave are winners, that is to say, there may be brave among the losers, then it cannot be concluded that every loser is a coward in the eyes of the fans, that is, the argument of the football coach cannot be established. ② The football coach's conclusion is: “Every loser is a wimp in the eyes of the fans.“ According to the conditions on which the coach's argument is based, this conclusion does not depend on the accuracy of the fans' judgment or whether the winner or loser is in fact brave or cowardly

context: When choosing food in the supermarket, many consumers tend to choose food packaged with transparent materials. The reason is that transparent packaging can directly see the food inside the package, so the heart has a sense of security.
question: Which of the following, if true, best casts doubt on the above psychological feelings?

B: Research from Penn State University in the United States shows that exposure to light, no matter what kind of light, causes a change in the flavor of milk
C: Some transparent material packaging of food, sometimes people look at it, especially the stale vegetables and fruits.
D: Many countries in the world use a large number of anti-light packaging on food packaging.
explanation: Note the“ sense of security “at the end of the question stem. Light has a destructive effect on food nutrition, which strongly explains that consumers' so-called “sense of security“ is very problematic.

context: The glaciers in the Himalayan region where Mount Qomolangma is located are in danger of shrinking dramatically due to global warming caused by the rapid increase in carbon dioxide emissions. Research shows that the rapid melting is occurring in areas where Mount Everest's glaciers are concentrated between 5,000 and 6,000 meters above sea level, and these areas will only see ice freeze in winter rather than during the warmer season. Experts theorize that depending on future climate change trends, the rate of glacier loss in the Himalayas is likely to accelerate, and if temperatures continue to rise as predicted this century, glaciers in the region will eventually disappear
question: If the following are true, what most weakens the argument above is:
A: Glaciers in the Himalayas are shrinking by about 0.1% to 0.6% each year
B: Glaciers in other parts of the Himalayas are not sensitive to temperature changes
C: Glacier cover around Mount Everest has decreased by 33.3% in the past 50 year
D: Glaciers above 7,000 meters on Qomolangma show no signs of rapid meltin
explanation: First step, determine the question type. According to the word “weaken“ in the way of questioning, it is determined to weaken the argument. Second, look for arguments and arguments. The argument: Experts theorize that, depending on future climate change trends, the pace of glacier loss in the Himalayas is likely to accelerate. If temperatures continue to rise this century as predicted, the region's glaciers will eventually disappear. Evidence: Research shows that the rapid melting of glaciers in Mount Everest is occurring at an altitude of 5,000 to 6,000 meters, where ice will only be seen in winter rather than during the warm season. Step 3: Identify the options. Item A: Unclear item. Shrinking by about 0.1 percent to 0.6 percent per year does not necessarily lead to the loss of glaciers in the region. It is not debilitating. B) The glaciers in the region are disappearing. The region of the Himalayas where Mount Qomolangma is located. The region of the Himalayas where Mount Qomolangma is located. C) What is not clear? The decline of the past 50 years does not mean that it will eventually disappear without a debilitating effect. D) Add to the contrarian argument. By telling us for example that there are places where there is no rapid melting that is not affected by temperature, this weakens the argument that the rate of decline is likely to accelerate and will eventually disappear

context: Secondhand smoke is worse for non-smokers than the smokers themselves, according to an American study. While smokers damage their cardiovascular system, the system adjusts itself to counteract some of the effects of smoking, while non-smokers' bodies are unable to adapt to the changes caused by smoke inhalation. Therefore, the effect of passive smoking on non-smokers is much greater than the effect on smokers.
question: Which of the following, if true, supports the findings above?
A: Passive smoking is the third most preventable cause of death after active smoking and alcohol consumption
B: Smoking is responsible for more than 85% of lung cancer cases and 30% of all cancer deaths
C: Smokers and non-smokers form couples where the latter has a 30% higher risk of dying from heart disease
D: A 20-year smoker who smokes four packs of cigarettes a day is more likely to have a spouse who dies of lung cancer
explanation: Step one: Identify the arguments and arguments. Argument: The effect of passive smoking on non-smokers is far greater than that on smokers. Argument: Secondhand smoke is more harmful to non-smokers than to smokers themselves. While smokers damage their cardiovascular system, the system can regulate itself to counteract some of the effects of smoking, while non-smokers' bodies cannot adapt to the changes caused by smoke inhalation. Step 2: Look at the options. A) Preventable causes of death have nothing to do with the effects of passive smoking on smokers and non-smokers. B) Only the effects of smoking on smokers, but not on non-smokers. C) Smoking can have a more serious impact on non-smokers. It increases their risk of dying from heart disease by 30%. D) A smoker's spouse may die of lung cancer, but the effect is not clear. D) The effect is not clear

context: Moocs (MoOCs) are a newly emerging model of online course development. context: More and more computer software has been developed and applied to mechanical engineering, which makes the result that used to be obtained by complex mathematical calculation in the operation process of this field now can be obtained by simple operation of the computer. explanation: explanation: Because mathematics is becoming less and less important, colleges training mechanical engineers should greatly reduce the mathematics curriculum to make time for intensive teaching of other subjects

context: The graphical method is a common method used in geometry courses. This method makes the course relatively easy to learn because students gain an intuitive understanding of geometric concepts, which helps develop their ability to process symbols for abstract operations. Diagramming algebraic concepts is believed to have the same pedagogical effect, although a deeper understanding of mathematics is essentially abstract rather than imaginary.
question: Which of the following claims is most unlikely to be supported by the above statement
A: Visualization through diagrams is not the final step in mathematical understanding.
B: A person with a strong ability to process symbols of abstract operations does not necessarily have an abstract mathematical understanding.
C: The graphical method in geometry is an effective teaching method.
D: There exists a method of teaching which can be usefully applied to both geometry and algebra.
explanation: ① The explanation“ concludes that a deep understanding of mathematics is abstract rather than imaginary in nature, which shows that intuition through diagrams is not the last step in mathematical understanding. ② He concludes that a deep understanding of mathematics is abstract rather than imaginary in nature. Therefore, although intuitive diagrams are helpful for processing abstract operation symbols, without abstract mathematical understanding ability, it is difficult for him to have a strong ability to process abstract operation symbols. (3) It is concluded that the use of diagrams in geometry courses can help develop students' ability to deal with abstract symbols, which shows that training the ability to deal with abstract symbols is one of the goals of geometry courses. (5) The diagramming of algebraic concepts will produce the same teaching effect as the diagramming in geometry

context: Luye Kindergarten Parents' committee suggested that the kindergarten reduce the management fee by 5% ~ 10%, but this suggestion is risky if it is really implemented. Although parents may be able to reduce the monthly childcare fee, the cost of dealing with problems caused by the declining quality of kindergarten services may be higher.
question: Which of the following is most likely to be the hypothesis of the argument above?
A: There are many kindergartens now where the management fee is not very high.
B: The reduction of management fees may reduce the quality of the kindergarten's service.
C: The management fee of Luye Kindergarten is lower than the average level of the industry.
D: For kindergartens, the reduction of management fees will inevitably lead to a decrease in staff income
explanation: Since the management fee of the kindergarten is reduced, the service quality of the kindergarten will decline. It should be assumed that the reduction of management fee will reduce the service quality.

context: Life expectancy in Singapore has been on the rise since the early 1960s, and by the 21st century it had overtaken Japan to become the world's highest. At the same time, Singaporeans, like all developed countries, are experiencing an increasing incidence of cardiovascular disease due to the high fat content of their diet
question: Which of the following conclusions is most likely to follow from the above?
A: Although the incidence of cardiovascular diseases is increasing year by year in Singapore, this disease is not currently the leading cause of death in Singapore.
B: Singapore has the highest level of treatment for cardiovascular diseases in the world.
C: The treatment of the major diseases that killed Singaporeans in the 1960s must have substantially improved by the 21st century, if there has not been a substantial reduction in their incidence in the country.
D: Singaporeans tend to eat more fatty foods than Japanese people.
explanation: Assuming that by the 21st century, there will be no substantial reduction in the incidence of the major diseases that killed Singaporeans in the 1960s, and no substantial improvement in the level of treatment for these diseases, then it is impossible for the average life expectancy of Singapore to keep rising, let alone become the world's largest in the early 21st century.

context: A recent survey of all auto crash victims in Dole County found that 80 percent of severely injured drivers and front seat passengers were not wearing seat belts at the time of the crash. This suggests that by wearing seat belts, drivers and front seat passengers can substantially reduce their risk of serious injury in the event of an accident.

Item A, more than 20 percent of all drivers and front passengers in the survey were wearing seat belts at the time of the accident. That is, less than 80 percent of all people were not wearing seat belts, and 80 percent of people involved in accidents were not wearing seat belts. This means that not wearing seat belts really increases the risk of injury, which must be assumed. B) The driver and front passenger in the car compared with the rear passenger. C) It is not necessary to assume. D. All automobile accident victims in Dole County D. Most automobile accidents reported to the Dole County police

context: A comprehensive study of Edgar Allen's correspondence has revealed that not a single letter mentions his famous morphine addiction. Based on this evidence, it is safe to say that it is incorrect to say that he was addicted to morphine, and that reports suspecting his addiction are untrue.

B: His income from writing is insufficient to support his morphine addiction.
C: He was unable to communicate extensively while under the influence of morphine addiction.
D: Fear of consequences would not have prevented him from pointing out in his correspondence that he had a morphine addiction.
explanation: Edgar Allen's addiction to morphine is not mentioned in any of his letters proving that Edgar Allen was not an endorphin addict.“ A. no, no, no, no, no. B) It is not necessary to assume that, even if his income from writing is insufficient to support his morphine addiction, he may have other sources of income sufficient to support his addiction.
