context: The fifth axiom of Euclidean geometric systems asserts that in the same plane a point beyond the line may and only may a line be drawn parallel to the line. In the history of mathematical development, many mathematicians doubted and worried whether this axiom was indisputably true.
question: Which of the following must be true for the mathematician's doubts above to be true
A: Only I. I. In the same plane, a point beyond the line may not be able to draw a line parallel to the line.
B: Only Ⅱ. Ⅱ. It is possible to make more than one line parallel to a straight line on the same plane through an outer point.
C: Only Ⅲ. Ⅲ. If it is impossible to make more than one line parallel to the line at a point beyond the line on the same plane, it is also possible to make only one line parallel to the line.
D: Ⅰ, Ⅱ and Ⅲ. ⅰ. In the same plane, a point beyond the line may not be able to draw a line parallel to the line. Ⅱ. On the same plane, it is possible to make more than one line parallel to the line by passing a point outside the line. Ⅲ. On the same plane, if it is not possible to make more than one line parallel to the line at a point beyond the line, then it may not be possible to make only one line parallel to the line.
explanation: First step, summarize the conditions for the explanation. Let p mean “a line can be drawn parallel to this line when passing a point beyond the line“, and q means “only a line can be drawn parallel to this line when passing a point beyond the line“. The fifth axiom is to conclude that “p and q“. For the doubt about the fifth axiom to hold, “p and q“ must be false. “p and q“ is false if and only if there is at least one false statement between p and q, but p itself need not be false and q itself need not be false. That is to say, for the doubt about the fifth axiom to hold, it must be concluded that there is at least one false statement in p and q, but it must not be concluded that p is false, and it must not be concluded that q is false. Step 2: Answer parsing. Option I concludes that p is false. For the doubt about the fifth axiom to be true, I need not be true. Option II concludes that q is false. For the doubt about the fifth axiom to be true, item Ⅱ need not be true. Option III asserts that if q is true, then p is false, which is equivalent to concluding that there is at least one false statement in p and q. For the doubt about the fifth axiom to be true, option Ⅲ must be true.

context: A group of researchers reported that compared with people whose heart rate was less than 58 beats per minute, people whose heart rate was more than 78 beats per minute had a 39 percent higher risk of heart attack or other cardiovascular problems, a 77 percent higher risk of death from such causes, and a 65 percent higher overall mortality rate. context: Fuxian Lake worm is a Devonian Chengjiang fauna, belongs to the relatively primitive type of euarthropod, adult 10 cm long, has 31 individual segments, the exoskeleton is divided into head, chest, abdomen three parts, its back and abdomen segments number is not consistent. context: Euripides, the ancient Greek dramatist, in his late works does not adhere to the strict conventions of poetic structure as he did in his early works. A recently discovered play by Euripides contains lines that adhere to those rules as strictly as his earlier plays, so it must have been written by Euripides at an earlier time.
question: Which of the following is the assumption made by the above argument?
A: Ancient playwrights tended to be more reluctant to break certain rules in their later years than in their earlier on
B: Euripides did not write any plays late in his career that imitated the style of his earlier works
C: As his writing progressed, Euripides increasingly escaped the conventions of his poetic structure
D: Late in his career, Euripides was the only dramatist of his time who made an effort to break the mould of poetry
explanation: First step, determine the question type. According to the “hypothesis“ in the way of questioning, it is determined to strengthen the argument. Second, look for arguments and evidence. Argument: A recently discovered play by Euripides has verses that adhere to those conventions as strictly as his earlier plays, so the play must have been written by Euripides at an early stage. Argument: Euripides did not adhere to the rules of poetic structure in his later works as strictly as he did in his earlier plays. Step three: Identify the options. A: Irrelevant. I am not sure whether it is the rule observed in the early period. It has nothing to do with whether the work is created in the early period. B: Add premises. The later period has not written any plays that imitate the style of its earlier works, the earlier works have the conventional characteristic of conforming to the structure of the poem, the later works do not have such characteristic, then according to the recent plays have the characteristic of conforming to the conventional structure of the poem must be the early plays, which complement the preconditions for the validity of the argument and have the effect of strengthening it. C) Ambiguity. Increasingly get rid of the rules of poetic structure, not sure whether there are still works in strict compliance with the rules in his late period, cannot judge the time of this work, does not have a strengthening effect. D: Unclear item. The only writer who breaks the mould of poetry, who is not sure whether any of his later works exist in strict conformity with the mould, who is not sure what period the work is from, does not reinforce.

context: In human history, continuous technological development and large-scale population movements do not seem to have significantly changed the climatic niche of human beings, and human beings have been concentrated in a relatively narrow climatic interval. However, more and more studies show that global warming will bring about a series of negative impacts on biodiversity, ecosystem services, agricultural production activities and human health. Based on current climate change trends, the researchers speculate that future intensification of climate change may lead to an increased risk of large-scale climate migration.
question: Which of the following, if true, most weakens the conclusion above?
A: Human beings need suitable climate conditions for survival, and climate change will lead to rapid geographical shift of suitable climate conditions.
B: A global temperature increase of 1 degree Celsius based on current temperatures is likely to cause populations in some regions to deviate from climatic niches.
C: On the current trajectory of climate change, the hot zone will extend to 19% of the global surface by 2070.
D: D: Global warming has, to some extent, accelerated the spread of certain infectious diseases and has had a bad effect on people's health
explanation: Cause: Future climate change intensifies. First → Result: The risk of large-scale climate migration rises.

context: The beating of the heart causes blood circulation. For the same person, the faster the heart rate, the greater the amount of blood entering the circulation per unit time. The red blood cells in the blood transport oxygen. Generally speaking, the more oxygen a person gets through the blood in a given period of time, the better his physical ability and performance. Therefore, to improve athletes' performance in sports, they should be trained more at high altitudes, where the number of red blood cells per unit volume of blood in the body is higher than at lower altitudes.
question: Which of the following must be assumed by the argument of the stem?
A: Altitude has no effect on the heart rate of the athletes
B: Athletes' heart rate at high altitude is not lower than that at low altitude
C: Athletes have a slower heart rate than the average person
D: D: Training at high altitudes can increase the heart rate of athle
explanation: First step, determine the explanation. According to the “must assume“ in the question, it is determined to strengthen the argument. Second, look for arguments and evidence. Argument: In order to improve the competitive level of athletes in sports competitions, they should strengthen their training at high altitudes. Argument: ① For the same person, the higher the heart rate, the more blood goes into circulation per unit time, the red blood cells in the blood carry oxygen, the more oxygen a person gets through the blood circulation per unit time, the better his physical ability and performance. ② At high altitudes, the number of red blood cells per unit volume of blood in the body is higher than at low altitudes. Step 3: Identify the options. Item A: Add to the evidence. A) To support an argument. If altitude has an effect on heart rate, it is not clear whether it is positive or negative. The conclusion is still valid. (B) Make a connection. The heart rate at high altitude is not lower than that at low altitude, thus improving the level of competition and enhancing the effect of higher altitude with more red blood cells. By using negative substitution, if the athletes' heart rate at high altitude is lower than that at low altitude, though the number of red blood cells in the blood will increase at high altitude, the heart rate will slow down, which will lead to the inability to obtain more oxygen through more blood circulation, which has a negative effect on physical performance, and there is no need to train at high altitude, which negates the argument. Therefore, it must be assumed. C) What do you think of it? The athlete's heart rate is slower than that of the average person. It is not certain whether he can improve his performance at high altitude. D) to add to the argument. D) The increased heart rate of athletes trained at high altitudes further supports the argument. If the athlete's heart rate does not increase at high altitude, it is not clear whether it will remain the same or decrease, the conclusion is still possible and therefore not necessary to assume.

context: Abnormal lipid metabolism is not simply caused by consuming too much fat. If you eat a large amount of sugar every day, it will also cause abnormal fat metabolism. If left untreated, abnormal lipid metabolism can lead to a variety of complications.

B: Only changes in diet and lifestyle habits can effectively improve the abnormal lipid metabolism.
C: Unless a large amount of greasy food with a high fat content is consumed daily, it will not cause elevated blood lipids.
D: If you do not eat a large amount of sugar every day, it will not cause elevated blood lipid.
explanation: ① Eating a lot of greasy food with high fat content every day (P1) → causing elevated blood lipid (Q1); ② Eating a lot of sugar every day (P2) → causing abnormal lipid metabolism (Q2); ③ not timely treatment of abnormal blood lipid metabolism (P3) I → cause a variety of complicated diseases (Q3).

context: The World Health Organization has conducted a follow-up survey on the health effects of blood donation worldwide. The participants were divided into three groups. The first group of subjects had more than two blood donation records, the most up to dozens of times; The second group had only one record of blood donation, and the third group had never donated blood. The rates of cancer and heart disease were 0.3 percent and 0.5 percent respectively in the first group, 0.7 percent and 9 percent in the second, and 2 percent and 7 percent in the third. Some experts have come to the conclusion that donating blood can help reduce the risk of cancer and heart disease. These two diseases have become the leading killers of the elderly, not only in developed but also in developing countries. Therefore, donating blood benefits everyone and kills two birds with one stone.
question: Which of the following, if true, would weaken the conclusion above?
A: Only I. ⅰ. Respondents over 60 years old accounted for 60% of the first group, 70% of the second group, and 80% of the third group.
B: Only Ⅱ. Ⅱ. Blood donors have to undergo a strict physical examination before donating blood and generally have a better constitution.
C: Only Ⅲ. ⅲ. The number of subjects in the survey: 170 in the first group, 300 in the second group and 700 in the third group.
D: Only Ⅰ and Ⅱ. ⅰ. Survey respondents over 60 percent in the first group, 70 percent in the second group and 80 percent in the third group. Ⅱ. Blood donors have to undergo a strict physical examination before donating blood and generally have a better constitution.
explanation: If the check item I is true, the conclusion in the explanation is weakened because in general, the older people are, the more likely they are to develop cancer and heart disease, and the more elderly the group, the higher the incidence of these two diseases. Otherwise, the reverse is true. The incidence in the first group was lower than in the second group, which in turn was lower than in the third. But check I also states that the proportion of people over 60 years old in the first group is lower than in the second group, which is lower than in the third group. Therefore, it is very likely that the phenomenon described in the question is not caused by the amount or presence of blood donations, but by differences in age or distribution. Check item Ⅱ indicates that blood donors have a good constitution before they donate blood. Therefore, good constitution is not caused by blood donation. It is formed long before blood donation. Therefore, compared with the first, two groups and the third group, the first two groups of objects have blood donation records, at least that they have a good physique before the first blood donation, and the third group of objects has never donated blood, their physique is not known, some of them poor physique is difficult to be screened by the way of blood donation physical examination, So the higher incidence of cancer and heart disease in the third group is quite natural, not caused by blood donation. From this point of view, check ⅱweakens the conclusion of the question. Check Ⅲ indicates the number of objects, which is irrelevant to the conclusion in the question stem. Because what matters is the incidence in each group, not the total number of people.

context: There is a wasp that procreates by parasitism, capable of infusing just the right number of its own eggs among the eggs of various insects of different sizes suitable for its offspring. If it infuses too many eggs in the host's eggs, its larvae die in competition with each other for lack of space and nourishment; If it infuses too few eggs, the excess nutrients in the host egg will rot, which in turn causes the larvae to die.
question: If the above statement is true, which of the following related statements must also be true
A: Only I. ⅰ. Among the mechanisms of parasitic reproduction described above is the ability of the wasp to accurately distinguish the egg size of its host.
B: only Ⅲ. ⅲ. wasps are more likely to kill parasitic larvae if they inject too many eggs than if they inject too few eggs.
C: Only Ⅰ and Ⅱ. Ⅰ. Among the mechanisms of parasitic reproduction described above is the ability of the wasp to accurately distinguish the egg size of its host. Ⅱ. More of these wasps were found in colonies with larger eggs than in colonies with smaller eggs.
D: Ⅰ, Ⅱ and Ⅲ. Ⅰ. Among the mechanisms of parasitic reproduction described above is the ability of the wasp to accurately distinguish the egg size of its host. Ⅱ. More of these wasps were found in colonies with larger eggs than in colonies with smaller eggs. Ⅲ. Wasps that inject too many eggs are more likely to cause the death of parasitic larvae than those that inject too few eggs
explanation: ① I must be true. Otherwise, if the wasp's parasitic reproduction mechanism does not include its ability to accurately distinguish the size of the host's eggs, it would not be able to inject just the right number of its own eggs into the eggs of various insects of different sizes suitable for its offspring. ②Ⅱ is not necessarily true, because it is entirely possible that insects with larger eggs are much less numerous than those with smaller eggs, and thus the wasps would be relatively concentrated in the insect aggregation areas with smaller eggs. ③Ⅲ is obviously not necessarily true. Therefore, the strong interference of Ⅱ makes this question more difficult.

context: Urine tests for certain sports competitions are divided into three types: positive, negative, and inconclusive. context: A city holds a music festival, and the music type is arranged as follows: (1) Choose at least one jazz or classical music. (2) If you do not choose folk music, choose pop music. (3) If jazz, rock. (4) Give up at least one rock or pop.
question: Which of the following is impossible if you follow the artistic director's advice?
A: No national music, but classical music.
B: Neither classical nor folk music is acceptable.
C: Neither classical nor folk music.
D: Both jazz and folk music are optional.
explanation: ① Jazz V classical, which is equivalent to: 7 jazz → classical music. ② Folk music → pop music. ③ Jazz → rock music, equivalent to rock → jazz music. ④ Rock music V pop music is equivalent to pop music → rock music. From ②, ④, ③ and ①, we can get: ③ folk music → pop → pop → jazz → classical music

context: The public transport sector in big cities is struggling with a deficit. Passengers complain about late buses and broken vehicles, fewer services and higher fares than they were used to paying. For all of these reasons, and because gasoline prices are not prohibiting, fewer riders are using public transportation, adding to the deficit.
question: Which of the following statements about the relationship between bus ridership and gas prices is most supported by the text above
A: As the price of gasoline goes up, so does the number of bus passengers
B: Bus ridership continued to decline even as gas prices went up
C: If gas prices rise to alarming levels, bus ridership will rise
D: The price of petrol is always low enough to make private transport cheaper than public transport, so fluctuations in petrol prices are unlikely to affect bus ridership.
explanation: The number of passengers has been reduced due to various problems with the buses and the fact that petrol prices have not reached unnervingly high levels. A: Because if the price of gasoline does not rise to the alarming level, then many people will still take their own cars, and the number of bus passengers will not necessarily rise. B: The opposite is true. C: Part of the reason why the number of bus passengers has decreased is that some passengers can take their own cars. D: Bus ridership has decreased because gas prices are not so high as to make people afraid, so fluctuations in gas prices affect bus ridership.

context: Metro line 1234 has been put into operation in a city. Each subway line takes the same time to run and stop at each station. Xiao Zhang, Xiao Wang and Xiao Li all work in the same unit near the Beikou subway Station. One morning, all three of them get on Line 1 at Changqing Station at the same time, but they have different ideas about the bus route. It is known that: (1) If Line 1 is crowded, Xiao Zhang will take 2 stops to Line 3 and then take 3 stops to Beikou Station. If Line 1 is not crowded, Zhang will take 3 stops, then transfer to Line 2, and then take 4 stops to Beikou station. (2) Only when Line 1 is crowded, Xiao Wang will take Line 3 after 2 stops and then take another 3 stops to Beikou Station. (3) If Line 1 is not crowded, Xiao Li will take 4 stops and then transfer to Line 4, 3 stops and then transfer to Line 3 and then take 1 stop to Beikou Station. (4) Subway Line 1 is not crowded that morni
question: Given the same total transfer and walk time for all three people, which of the following is most likely to be inconsistent with the above information?
A: Xiao Wang and Xiao Li arrive at the same time.
B: Xiao Zhang and Xiao Wang arrive at the same time.
C: Xiao Li arrived at work before Xiao Zhang.
D: Xiao Zhang arrives at work before Xiao Wang.
explanation: Substituting condition (4) for Condition (1) and (3) respectively, it can be obtained that Zhang takes 3 stations, then transfers to Line 2, and then takes 4 stations to Beikou Station; Xiao Li takes 4 stations and then transfers to Line 4, 3 stations and then transfers to Line 3, and then takes 1 station to reach Beikou Station. Xiao Zhang takes 7 stops and Xiao Li takes 8 stops. The total transfer and walking time of the three people is the same. We can see that Xiao Zhang arrived at the unit earlier than Xiao Li. Xiao Wang does not know the time

context: Xiao Li destroyed the green space beside his guardrail and planted cucumbers. The property management staff of the community reminded Xiao Li that the green space beside the guardrail was a public green space and belonged to the owner of the community. The property issued a notice of rectification to this end, requiring Xiao Li to restore the green space within a time limit. Xiao Li responded by saying, “Am I not from the community? Since the green space beside the guardrail belongs to the owner of the community, it certainly belongs to me. Therefore, I have the right to grow melons on my own land.“
question: Which of the following arguments is most similar to Xiao Li's error?
A: Everyone is responsible for his wrongdoings, Trabecular is not responsible for his wrongdoings, so Trabecular is not wrong this time.
B: All the orchids on display at the expo were sold out. Li Yang bought a pot of flowers at a high price. It can be seen that what Li Yang bought must be orchids
C: The army of all the knights of Molby was invincible in Europe at that time, and King Yin-ya was one of the knights of Molby, so King Yin-ya was invincible in Europe at that time.
D: It is impossible for any one person to master all the knowledge in today's world. Geocentric theory is not knowledge in today's world. Therefore, some people can master geocentric theory
explanation: explanation: The explanation for the debate is that “Since the green space beside the guardrail belongs to the owner of the community, I am a member of the community, so the green space beside the guardrail also belongs to me“. “The owner of the community“ is a whole, but “I am a member of the community“, “I“ is only the individual of this whole. Therefore, the properties of the whole do not necessarily belong to the individual. Therefore, from the properties of the whole, it follows that the individuals that make up it must also belong to it. There is a logical error of “decomposition“

context: In a company year-end party, the host in 3 small boxes each put a prize, let Li, Guo, Xiao Yang, Xiao Li four people guess each box put several prize. Xiao Li said: “No. 1 box is the third prize, No. 2 box is the grand prize, No. 3 box is the first prize“ Guo said: “No. 1 box is the second prize, No. 2 box is the grand prize, No. 3 box is the fourth prize“ Xiao Yang said: “No. 1 box is the consolation prize, No. 2 box is the third prize, No. 3 box is the fifth prize“ Xiao Li said: “Box 1 is the second prize, box 2 is the fourth prize, box 3 is the consolation prize“ if a person happens to guess two, the other three people only guess one.
question: Then in the second box is
A: Special prize.
B: Fifth prize.
C: Consolation prize.
D: Fourth Prize.
explanation: There are a total of 5 to guess correctly. You can guess a maximum of 2 correctly in the first column, 2 correctly in the second column and 1 correctly in the third column. Therefore, guess 2 correctly in the first column, 2 correctly in the second column, and 1 correctly in the third column, therefore, the second box is the grand prize.

context: A creative competition will be held in the university campus. Seven people, A, B, C, D, E, Yi and Geng, have signed up for the competition. (1) The seven people are divided into three groups, and the number of people in each group is different; (2) both A and D are in the largest group; (3) If B and D are not in the same group, B is in the same group with only one other person; (4) B, E, and E are not in the same group, and E and A are in the same group.
question: If you don't team up with anyone, then team up with E and Hepton. The following statement must be true?
A: E and C are in the same group.
B: Geng and A are in the same group.
C: B and B are in the same group.
D: C and Geng are in the same group.
explanation: ① The seven people are divided into three groups, each with a different number of people; ② Both A and D are in the largest group; ③ B and D are not in the same group → B is only in the same group as another person; ④ B, E and himself are not in the same group; ⑤ he is not in a group with anyone → E and hepton are in a group. According to condition (1), it can be determined that the group is 1, 2 and 4. According to condition (2), it can be obtained that A and D are in the third group. Combining condition ② and ④, we can get: A, D and E are in the third group, and B and D are in different groups. Substitute “different groups of B and D“ into condition ③ : B is in a group with only one other person, so B is in the second group. ④ B, E and I are not in the same group, but they are in the first group. Step 2: Since “one person in a group“, this era into the condition ⑤ can be: E and Geng a group, in the third group. Therefore, the remaining C is in the second group. Group 1 (1 person) : already; The second group (2 people) : B, C; The third group (4 people) : A, D, E, Geng.

context: Li Dong is good at arguing and also likes sophistry. Once he argued, “Zheng Qiang knows the number 87654321. Chen Mei's phone number happens to be 87654321, so Zheng Qiang knows Chen Mei's phone number.“
question: Which of the following is most similar to the mistake made by Li Dong Zhanzhong
A: Yellow soldier believes that the morning star appears in the morning, but the morning star is actually the Twilight star, so Yellow soldier believes that the Twilight star appears in the morning.
B: Gold bricks are made up of atoms, and atoms are not visible to the naked eye, so gold bricks are not visible to the naked eye.
C: Chinese people are industrious and brave, Li LAN is Chinese, so Li LAN is industrious and brave.
D: All ants are animals, so all big ants are big animals.
explanation: Evaluation type questions. The logical error is the improper substitution between the general concept of numbers and the particular concept of telephone numbers.

context: In 1964, the Genovese case occurred in New York, USA. A girl named Genovese was killed by ten thousand men with knives on her way home. Within 30 minutes of the murder, 38 neighbors heard the victim's cry for help. Many of them went to the window to watch for a long time, but no one went to the rescue, or even lifted a hand, called the police in time, which made an undeserved tragedy come true.
question: What is the most appropriate explanation for the above phenomenon
A: It is a loss of humanity for the public to see others in distress and refuse to help them.
B: The public witnessed the incident and did not help, perhaps because the presence of others inhibited the motivation to help, leading to the dispersion of social responsibility.
C: In the face of danger people tend to protect themselves
D: There is no time to delay in moral education for citizens
explanation: During the process of the crime, many people heard cries for help and some saw the crime scene, but there was no help and no police explanation.

context: Among the seven newly elected members of the Student Union of a certain school, there are 1 Dalian, 2 northern, 1 Fuzhou, 2 special students (i.e., students with special expertise) and 3 poor students (i.e., students with special financial difficulties).
question: Suppose that the above introduction concerns all members of the student Union, then the following statements regarding the member are consistent with the question, except
A: Both exceptional students are poor students.
B: The exceptional students are all southerners.
C: Dalian people are exceptional.
D: D: Fuzhou people are not poor students
explanation: Clear number of members: There are a total of 7 members of the university's Student Union. The number of clear identities: 1 from Dalian, 2 from the north, 1 from Fuzhou, 2 exceptional students, 3 poor students, 9 identities in total. Since this person from Dalian must be one of the two people from the north, there are only 8 identities corresponding to 7 people, so there must be only 1 identity overlap. If the two special students are poor students, there are only 6 people with identities in the question, which is inconsistent with the statement that there are 7 members of the Student Union of the university. Fuzhou people must be southerners, but southerners are not necessarily Fuzhou people.

context: The role of the microbiome in the Earth's ecosystems and human health is beyond imagination. It will not only help us overcome the challenges we face today, but also provide us with ways to survive in the future. One of the reasons for this is that microorganisms cooperate with each other so that they are more stable and efficient in the ecosystem. And giving the microbiome more power than any individual microbe.
question: The following, if true, best support the above view:
A: The National Microbiome Program in the United States is designed to advance cutting-edge microbial scientific research in all ecosystems, natural and man-made worlds
B: As an emerging industry, biopesticides and biofertilizers have been booming in recent years, and their international market share has been increasing rapidly year by year
C: When a variety of microorganisms are cultivated together, the stability and adaptability of the biological system are greatly improved, and the degradation efficiency of some harmful compounds is also improved
D: microbial sites in brewing provide a variety of microbial resources, from which high efficiency cellulose degrading mold, high ethanol synthesis yeast, et
explanation: Step one: Identify the arguments and arguments. Argument: Microbes will greatly help mankind overcome the existential challenges we face today, and provide us with ways to survive in the future. The argument: The ability of microorganisms to cooperate with each other allows them to function more steadily and efficiently in ecosystems, giving the microbiome more powerful capabilities than individual microbes. Step 2: Look at the options. A: Can microorganisms help humans overcome the challenges of survival and provide a way for people to survive? The research content of the National Microbiome Program in the United States is inconsistent, cannot be strengthened or excluded. B: The argument is about whether microorganisms can help humans overcome the challenges of survival and provide a way for human survival. The argument is about the market share of biopesticides and biofertilizers. The topic is inconsistent and cannot be strengthened or excluded. C) If a variety of microorganisms are cultivated together, the stability and adaptability of the microbial system will be improved, and the efficiency of decomposition of harmful compounds will also be improved. It is pointed out that the cooperation between microorganisms can indeed play a more powerful role. D: The argument is about whether microorganisms can help human beings overcome the challenges of survival, to provide a way for human survival, said that brewing microbes can synthesize yeast, does not involve a variety of microorganisms cooperation, whether there is a more powerful function, the topic is not consistent, can not be strengthened, excluded

context: A middle school has experimented with student behavior evaluation system since 2010. Recently, the school's student Affairs office surveyed students about their satisfaction with the evaluation system. Statistics show that students with high scores are highly satisfied with the evaluation system. The Student Affairs Office concluded that students with high performance were satisfied with the system.
question: Which of the following assumptions did the office base its conclusion on?
A: Students with low scores are generally dissatisfied with the evaluation system.
B: The students who do well are the students who get high marks.
C: Students with high scores were motivated by the evaluation system and consciously improved their behavior.
D: Students satisfied with the evaluation system will automatically strive for better performance.
explanation: explanation: The students with high scores are satisfied with the evaluation system. The students with good performance are satisfied with the evaluation system. A: Only for the premise, not for the argument relationship, so it is not the conclusion of the hypothesis. B: “High score“ correlates with “good performance“. B: Because they are not the same concept, if there is no choice B, there is a suspicion of “stealing the concept“. C: You get high marks and do well. D: This is an inversion of causality

context: Most of the Earth's surface is covered by the ocean, and life is born in the ocean. However, it is estimated that 80 percent of the Earth's species live on land, while only 15 percent live in the oceans, and the remaining 5 percent live in fresh water. The researchers believe that the physical layout of habitats on land may be more fragmented than in the ocean, one of the main reasons for the greater diversity of species on land
question: Which of the following, if true, most strengthens the researcher's argument above?
A: The earth's surface can be divided into five temperature zones: tropical, South temperate, North temperate, South frigid and North frigid, with a great diversity of species in each temperature zon
B: The deep sea is basically like a refrigerator compared to the shallow sunlit coastal regions, and the door has been closed for a long time, and the species are far less abundant than in the shallow seas
C: According to one archipelagic record, natural selection can even, over time, transform different populations of the same species on two islands into distinct species
D: Forests cover much of the land, while leaves and branches form new habitats, and corals in the oceans do the same, but not so much cover the sea floor
explanation: First step, determine the explanation. According to the word “strengthen“ in the way of questioning, it is determined to strengthen the argument. Second, look for arguments and evidence. Argument: The physical layout of habitats on land is likely to be more fragmented than in the ocean, and is one of the main reasons for the greater diversity of life on land. The argument: It is estimated that 80 percent of the Earth's species live on land, compared to 15 percent in the sea. Step 3: Identify the options. Item A: Unclear item. There are different temperature zones on the Earth's surface, and there are Marine and terrestrial environments in each of these zones. Therefore, the “large species difference“ discussed in this article does not refer specifically to the terrestrial environment and is not helpful. B) What is the difference between the Earth and the Earth? B) The difference between the deep sea and the shallow coastal areas is the inconsistent degree of light exposure, which makes the species diverse, but does not involve the comparison of the physical layout of the land and the ocean. C) to add to the argument. (C) The abundance of life on land is reinforced by the fact that “natural selection“ has made the islands more abundant. D) What is the difference between islands and islands? D) The area covered by land forests is larger than the area covered by corals on the seafloor

context: When a child has a cold, the mucus in the nose and throat is caused by the cold virus and produced. Dairy products just get stuck in the throat, making it a little uncomfortable. When your child has a cold, you can continue to provide milk or other dairy products.

D) Dairy products stick in the throat and cause some discomfort. D) Dairy products can relieve the discomfort of colds or increase the production of mucus in the throat. (B) The milk products can make people feel better. (D) The milk products can make people feel better

context: Most of the elite athletes have good mental quality, most of the elite athletes have achieved good results in competition, and all of the athletes who have achieved good results in competition have trained hard.

context: The only way an economist can distinguish between normal goods and cheap goods is to look at how consumers react to changes in income. If people want less of something as their incomes go up, that's a low-grade good. Similarly, if people have less income, they want more low-grade goods.

A: Poor students at school often eat instant noodles and they often go to restaurants when they get A job after graduation. For these students, instant noodles are the lowest grade.
B: In an aging community with less need for gasoline and more need for home care services. Compared to gasoline, home care services are downmarket.
C: As people's income goes up, parents buy more designer clothes for their children and less when income goes down. Designer clothes are not cheap, not normal, but high quality.
D: Adults in upscale neighborhoods often buy expensive model cars for their children to use as toys, while children in shantytowns rarely have any toys
explanation: explanation: As income increases, the demand for low-grade goods decreases; As income decreases, the demand for low-grade goods increases. A. The demand for instant noodles increases when people are poor, but decreases when people are rich. B) The demand for instant noodles increases, but the income increases. C) The famous brand clothing is a high-end product, but it does not involve normal and low-grade products. D) People with money buy toys. People without money don't buy toys

context: The neighborhood committee holds a meeting of community residents' representatives. After the meeting, the participants sit together and chat. According to the chat, the director of the neighborhood committee was informed that: Xiao Wang and Xiao Zhang are neighbors, and Xiao Zhang and Xiao Li are neighbors; Xiao Zhao and Xiao Li are good friends, and Xiao Li and Qian are good friends.
question: If all the above information informed by the neighborhood committee director is true, which of the following must be true?
A: Only I. I, Xiao Zhang and Xiao Wang are neighbors.
B: Only Ⅱ. Ⅱ, Xiao Wang and Xiao Li are neighbors.
C: Only Ⅰ and Ⅱ. Ⅰ, Xiao Zhang and Xiao Wang are neighbors. Ⅱ, Xiao Wang and Xiao Li are neighbors.
D: Ⅰ, Ⅱ and Ⅲ. Ⅰ, Xiao Zhang and Xiao Wang are neighbors. Ⅱ, Xiao Wang and Xiao Li are neighbors. Xiao Zhao and Xiao Qian are good friends.
explanation: Neighbor“ in “Xiao Wang and Xiao Zhang are neighbors“ is a symmetric relationship. From the nature of the symmetric relationship, we can know that Xiao Zhang and Xiao Wang are also neighbors. Therefore, item I must be true. In the sentences “Xiao Wang and Xiao Zhang are neighbors, and Xiao Zhang and Xiao Li are neighbors“, if we look at the “neighbors“ in one sentence alone, the relationship is symmetric; However, if the two sentences are taken as a whole, “neighbor“ is a non-transitive relationship. According to the meaning of non-transitive relationship, we can know that Xiao Wang and Xiao Li may or may not be neighbors. Therefore, ⅱmay be true, that is, not necessarily true. In the same way, “friends“ is a symmetric relation, but it is also a non-transitive relation. Therefore, item Ⅲ may be true, i.e. it is not necessarily true

context: Researchers found an algorithm error in software dedicated to functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) technology that is commonly used. They collected the resting results of 499 healthy people and found that their statistical methods had to be tested with real-world cases. This means that the software can sometimes get it so wrong that it shows activity even when the brain is at rest -- and the activity it shows is the product of its algorithms rather than the brains being studied actually being active.
question: Which of the following, if true, best supports the conclusion above?
A: The study conclusion can be obtained by fMRI data and compiled by relevant programs
B: fMRI captures changes in blood flow in the brain, but it is not effective in showing whether the brain is active or not
C: The fMRI software commonly used to diagnose brain function has a false positive rate of more than 70%
D: Only 30% of the results obtained by fMRI specialized software are further confirmed by confirmatory tests
explanation: Step one: Identify the arguments and arguments. Argument: Software can sometimes be so wrong that it shows activity even when the brain is at rest -- the activity it shows is the product of the software algorithm, rather than the brain being studied actually being active. The argument: Taking the resting results of 499 healthy people, the statistical method has yet to be tested with actual medical records. Step 2: Examine the options one by one. A: Research results can be compiled using the technology to obtain data. The topic is inconsistent, cannot be strengthened, or excluded. B: fMRI can capture changes in blood flow, but can not effectively show whether the brain is active or not, indicating that the fMRI software does have problems, has a strengthening effect, reserved; Item C: The false positive rate of fMRI software is high, indicating that the error rate of conclusion is very high. Then the software is indeed wrong sometimes, but also has the effect of strengthening, retention; D) The results obtained by the software can sometimes be wildly wrong. D) The results obtained by the software can be wildly wrong. B can prove that the software does have problems, but it can't prove how big the problem is and whether it is wrong. C clearly says that the false positive rate is high, that is, the error probability is very high, and more clearly proves that the software sometimes is wrong

context: The area of equatorial rainforest in Country H is decreasing at an alarming rate every year, causing global concern. However, data from satellite photos show that last year, Japan's rainforest shrank at a much lower rate than in previous years. Last year, the government of Japan spent millions of dollars to stop deforestation and prevent forest fires. The government claims that the satellite data show that its efforts to protect the equatorial rainforest are having a significant effect
question: Which of the following, if true, most undermines the above conclusion of the Government of H?
A: Last year, the financial input of Country H to protect the equatorial rainforest was significantly higher than in previous years.
B: Last year, the area of equatorial rainforest in Country G adjacent to Country H decreased significantly less than in previous years.
C: Last year's dry season in Country H saw unusually large areas of sustained rainfall.
D: State H spends only a small percentage of its annual fiscal expenditure on rainforest protection
explanation: First step, summarize the conditions for the explanation. Arguments: (1) Last year, the shrinkage ratio of the rainforest area in Country H was significantly lower than that in previous years. (2) Last year, the government of Country H spent millions of dollars to stop deforestation and prevent forest fires. Conclusion: The government's efforts to protect the equatorial rainforests have achieved remarkable results. Last year, the reduction rate of the rainforest area in Country H was significantly lower than that in previous years. This result was explained by the fact that the government of Country H spent millions of dollars to protect the equatorial rainforest. A significantly different explanation is put forward from that of the government of Country H. Therefore, if true, it strongly undermines the conclusion of the Government of H.

context: The year 2017 can be said to be an important year for the development of Chinese films. However, some film practitioners believe that China is a film country, but not a film power.

context: Changhong, Zhabei, Wudang, Dongfeng and Chaoyang districts of a city have all carried out environmental remediation actions. context: In the traditional society, there are few cultural products that the society can provide, and the public has little choice. A: The coming of the network society has completely changed the mode of interaction between people. It has nothing to do with the disappearance of common interests of the public. B: With the help of mobile Internet, the people with whom we interact most may not be around at all, which has nothing to do with the disappearance of common interests of the public. C: Modern technology has broken through the traditional pattern of differential order, and human relations are no longer based on regions, which has nothing to do with the disappearance of common interests and hobbies of the public. D: Social organizations can build contact platforms to organize related activities to develop interests and hobbies, which means that the development of the network and the emergence of human-computer interaction can create a platform for people to get along and communicate, and this platform can organize related activities to cultivate interests, there will be no disappearance of common interests of the public, directly weaken the argument, elected

context: Due to recent market changes, Green Island Company must increase its productivity by 10% in the next two years or it will go bankrupt. context: The legal music disc produced by W company sells for 25 yuan each, making a profit of 10 yuan; Pirated copies of such CDS cost only 5 yuan each. Therefore, if 100,000 copies of such pirated discs are sold, it will cause a profit loss of 1 million yuan for W Company.

context: The colors of the car of A, B, C and D are white, silver, blue and red. context: “It is generally believed that at the age of 80 a person's ability to understand and remember is significantly reduced compared with that at the age of 30. According to a recent survey, there is no significant difference between the comprehension and memory ability of an 80-year-old and a young person of 30 when playing mahjong. Therefore: the idea that comprehension and memory skills decline significantly at the age of 80 is untenable.
question: Which of the following, if true, most weakens the argument above?
A: Playing mahjong does not require comprehension and memory.
B: Playing Mahjong requires only low comprehension and memory.
C: Playing mahjong helps to improve one's understanding and memory

explanation: Explanation “:“ There is no significant difference between an 80-year-old man and a 30-year-old man's understanding and memory when playing mahjong. Conclusion: Comprehension and memory do not decline significantly at the age of 80. A healthy 80-year-old can lift a kilogram of rice just as easily as a young person, but it does not follow that there is no significant loss of arm strength at age 80, because lifting a kilogram requires less strength.

context: According to the survey, in 2010, 48 percent of people aged 18-24 were living with their parents, while in 2015, the proportion rose to 54 percent. Therefore, we conclude that in 2015, people in this age group were less able to live independently.
question: Which of the following is the assumption of the above argument?
A: People in this age group who live with their parents are not responsible for living expenses, etc.
B: From 2010 to 2015, the number of apartments suitable for single occupancy decreased
C: At this age, people who can live independently will never live with their parents
D: A number of people in the survey, although now living with their parents, had previously lived independently
explanation: From the fact that there are more people in this age group living with their parents in 2015 than in 2010, this explanation leads to the conclusion that people in this age group have worse independent living ability in 2015. Here, we need to take into account the fact that living with parents does not mean poor independent living ability, and many people with independent living ability will also live with their parents. If this situation is satisfied, the conclusion in the title cannot be reached. To reach this conclusion, we have to assume that people who live independently do not live with their parents.

context: Economist: A business is self-sustaining if it can make acceptable profits without government help. If a firm cannot make normal profits in an open and competitive market, then it is not self-generating. Unless an enterprise has the policy burden, it will not get the protection and subsidies from the government. Since state-owned enterprises have government protection and subsidies, they can make a profit even if they are not self-sustaining.
question: If the above statement is true, which of the following must be true?
A: If an enterprise is not self-generating, it will be eliminated from competition.
B: If an enterprise has government protection and subsidies, it will have policy burdens.
C: If an enterprise is not self-generating, it will be eliminated from the competition.
D: In an open and competitive market, every enterprise is self-sustaining
explanation: 1. An enterprise has no help from the government but can obtain acceptable profits → it has self-explanatory capacity; 2. An enterprise cannot gain normal profits in an open competitive market → it has no self-generating capacity; 3. An enterprise can get protection and subsidies from the government → there are policy burdens.

context: Weddings are visible, love is not; Love letters can be seen, missing can't be seen; Flowers visible, spring can not see; Fruit can be seen, but nutrition cannot be seen; Help is seen, care is unseen; The wind is seen, but the air is invisible; Diplomas are visible, but levels are not. A: Triangles can be divided into right triangle, obtuse triangle and acute triangle. The sum of the three inner angles of a right triangle is equal to 180°, the sum of the three inner angles of an obtuse triangle is equal to 180°, and the sum of the three inner angles of an acute triangle is equal to 180°. B: Chance“ trumps “necessity“. You see, the Olympic Games are full of suspense, which makes them exciting. C: A surgeon can look at X-rays when operating on a patient, a lawyer can look at a defense when defending a defendant, an architect can look at plans when building a house, and a teacher can look at various reference books when preparing a lesson. Then why shouldn't students be allowed to look at textbooks and other relevant materials when taking an exam
D: Roses are beautiful because all flowers are beautiful.
explanation: By summarizing several examples, the explanation“ has reached the general conclusion that“ things that are invisible are more valuable than things that are visible “, and uses incomplete induction. For A, there are only three types of triangles, and all of them satisfy the requirement that the sum of the internal angles equals 180 degrees. Therefore, the author has exhausted all possibilities and adopted complete induction. Is different from the question. B, the general conclusion that “chance“ trumps “necessity“ is reached through four examples, using the same method of incomplete induction as the question stem. C) We can draw an analogy from several concrete examples to another concrete example. D) The general conclusion that “all flowers are beautiful“ is used to demonstrate the individual conclusion that “roses are beautiful“

context: An American scholar did an experiment in which the tested children were shown three pictures, chicken, cow and grass, and then asked to classify them into two categories. The American scholar thus concluded that Chinese children are used to classifying things in relation to each other, while American children are used to classifying things in terms of the categories of entities to which they belong
question: Which of the following must be assumed by these scholars to reach their conclusion
A: Horses and grass are classified according to their relation to each other.
B: American children are accustomed to classifying cows and chickens according to the categories of entities to which they belong, as long as they group them together.
C: American children are not accustomed to classify things in relation to each other as long as they group cows and chickens together.

explanation: Enhanced title. The option that connects the argument and the conclusion is the correct one to choose

context: A new study finds that short-term consumption of a high-fat diet is good for the heart. When researchers artificially induced ischemic heart damage in mice late in the study, similar to what happens during a human heart attack, they found that mice fed a high-fat diet for 24 hours, one week, and two weeks had 70 percent less damaged heart tissue than mice fed a high-fat diet for six weeks and those fed a “vegetarian“ diet. The researchers believe this is because short-term exposure to the high-fat diet allows the heart muscle to gain more energy, increasing its ability to resist damage. It is thought that short-term consumption of a high-fat diet may protect heart function.
question: Which of the following is true and best supports the conclusion of the stem
A: If rats were given a“ meat diet “for one day and then switched to a vegetarian diet, their hearts were better able to withstand damage than those that had been given a vegetarian diet to begin with.
B: High-fat foods provide the body with the necessary materials and energy to carry out activities such as metabolism.
C: LDL cholesterol, which is found in high-fat foods, is essential to the human body.
D: D: To reduce the risk of heart disease, you should eat a balanced diet with adequate intake of fat and cholesterol
explanation: explanation: From the animal experiments, it is found that the heart tissue damage of mice fed a high-fat diet for 24 hours, one week and two weeks is 70% less than that of mice fed a high-fat diet for six weeks and those fed a vegetarian diet. Thus, it is concluded that short-term intake of a high-fat diet may protect the heart function

context: A study of 37,000 men aged 49 to 75 in one country found that nearly 2,000 of them had a stroke over a 10-year period; Those who ate chocolate regularly had a significantly lower risk of stroke than those who ate little or no chocolate. The researchers speculate that regular chocolate consumption may reduce stroke risk
question: Which of the following, if true, best supports the researchers' hypothes
A: Regular consumption of chocolate was found to regulate blood sugar levels in patients with hypoglycemia
B: Similar findings in women were consistent with these findings
C: Chocolate contains flavonoids, which have been shown to protect against stroke
D: In this study, some of the men who had had a stroke had a regular chocolate consumption
explanation: Step one: Identify the arguments and arguments. Argument: Regular consumption of chocolate may reduce the risk of stroke. The argument: A study of 37,000 people from a certain country men aged 49 to 75 found that nearly 2,000 of them had a stroke over a 10-year period. Those who ate chocolate regularly had a significantly lower risk of stroke than those who ate little or no chocolate. Step 2: Determine how to strengthen. If only one phenomenon is given as an example in the question stem, new evidence can be added to strengthen the argument. Step 3: Analyze the options. A, regular chocolate consumption regulates blood sugar levels in patients with hypoglycemia, does not indicate a relationship between chocolate consumption and a reduced risk of stroke, does not strengthen the argument; B) The study was conducted on men and the findings were universal, so the researchers' similar findings in women are consistent with the above findings and support the argument that regular chocolate consumption reduces stroke risk. C) The association between chocolate consumption and a lower risk of stroke is strengthened by the fact that chocolate contains flavonoids, which may protect against stroke. D) the fact that some of the men who had had strokes regularly consumed chocolate weakened the argument. But C was strengthened by the chocolate itself, so B was weaker than C.

context: A headhunter is a firm that takes a fee from its clients and then recruits the kind of talent that is badly needed but hard to find for its clients. context: There are the following guesses about the perpetrator of a case: (1) If A is the perpetrator, then B must be the perpetrator. (2) A is the perpetrator. (3) A or C is the perpetrator. (4) D is the perpetrator.
question: Given that A, B, C, and D must have a perpetrator and that only one of the above four guesses is correct, which of the following is correct?
A: A is the perpetrator, the others are not.
B: B is the perpetrator, the others are not.
C: C is the perpetrator, the others are not.
D: Ding is the perpetrator, the others are not.
explanation: Step 1: Symbolization. (1) A → B, which is equivalent to: A V b. (2) A. (3) A, V and C. (4) D. Method 1 of 2: Finding at least one True. Step 2: Without contradiction in four sentences, find at least one truth. If A is the perpetrator, then (2) is true; If A is not the perpetrator, then (1) is true. Therefore (1) and (2) are at least one true. Step 3: Determine whether other propositions are true or false. And since only one of the four statements is true, (1) and (2) are one true and one false, and (3) and (4) are both false. Step 4: Determine the true situation and determine whether the choices are true or false. If (3) and (4) are false, it can be seen that A, C and D are not the culprits. It is also known that A, B, C and D must have the perpetrator, so B is the perpetrator.

context: Studies of adults with migraines have revealed that a high percentage of sufferers have very complex syndromes. The syndrome has three symptoms: those who suffer from it experience extreme anxiety as early as their childhood; By the time they reach adolescence, they begin to suffer from migraines; By the time they reached 20, they also began to suffer from recurrent episodes of depression. Since this pattern is consistent and always starts with excessive anxiety, it follows that excessive anxiety in childhood is a cause of migraines and later depression.
question: The reasoning of the above argument is most vulnerable to criticism on which of the following grounds
A: It does not specify the percentage of people with migraine.
B: Its general statement is inconsistent with the evidence.
C: It does not prove that the subject is representative of migraine sufferers.
D: It does not exclude the possibility that all symptom features of the syndrome have a common cause.
explanation: explanation“ summarizes the three stages of development of migraine syndrome: anxiety disorder in childhood, migraine in adolescence, and depression after the age of 20. It is concluded that excessive anxiety in childhood is the cause of migraines and later depression. The apparent flaw in the reasoning is that it is possible for all three features of migraine syndrome to be the result of a single cause.

context: In order to investigate the current level of literacy, the experimenter listed 20 words and asked 30 literate people with a college education or above to read them. The reading results showed that most people only read 3 to 5 words correctly, very few people read more than 15 words correctly, and some people even read all of them wrong. The word “stumbling“ had the highest recognition rate, with 19 out of 30 people correctly pronouncing it. And “Quack, quack, quack“ all got it wrong. The overall mispronunciation rate for all 20 words was nearly 80 percent. The experimenter concluded that literacy levels are not improving, or even declining
question: Which of the following, if true, most casts doubt on the experimenter's conclusion?
A: The 20 words chosen by the experimenter are not representative.
B: None of the 30 readers selected by the experimenter had a PhD.
C: The experimenter selected 20 words that are not commonly used in popular Internet language.
D: About 50% of the experimenter's 30 general readers failed in college.
explanation: Weakening title. ① From the analysis of the title, we can see that the title is an enumeration induction reasoning, that is, to draw a general conclusion based on some samples and some circumstances. The current literacy level of the people has not improved, and even declined. The conclusion is based on a survey. ② In enumeration induction, the examples listed must be representative of the conclusions, and no special samples can be found, otherwise it will make the mistake of “overgeneralizing the whole“ or “bias the sample“. The conclusion is based on “20 words“ in the stem, but if they are not common words, they will lose their representativeness and the conclusion will lose its basis

context: There are fifty families in a village, and each family has a dog. The head of the village said that there were sick dogs in the village and allowed every family to check whether other families' dogs were sick, but not their own dogs. If they figured out that their own dog was a sick dog, they had to shoot their own dog. But they were not allowed to tell anyone if they saw someone else's dog as a sick dog, and they had no right to shoot someone else's dog, only their own dog. Then on the first day there was no shooting, and on the second day there was no shooting, and on the third day there was a burst of shooting.
question: How many sick dogs are there in the village
A: Two.
B: Three.
C: Four.
D: Fifty.
explanation: Because the village chief says there are sick dogs in the village, there should be at least one sick dog in the village. We can make the following hypothesis: If there is only one sick dog, the owner of the sick dog will find that other dogs are normal, deduce that his dog is the sick dog, and will kill his dog on the first day. On the other hand, it means that everyone can see other people's sick dogs, and there is more than one sick dog in the village. The absence of gunfire on the first day means there is more than one sick dog in the village. If there are two sick dogs in the village, the owner of the sick dog will find out that someone else has a sick dog and will not shoot his dog on the first day. When he finds that the owner of the other sick dog did not kill his dog on the first day, he assumes that the other person also saw a sick dog, and they will both shoot their dog the next day. There were no gunshots the next day, suggesting that there were more than two sick dogs in the village. If there are three sick dogs in the village, the owner of the sick dog will find out that other people have two sick dogs and will not shoot his dog for the first two days. When the owner of the other two sick dogs did not shoot his own dogs for the previous two days, he assumed that the other person had also seen the two sick dogs, and the three men shot their own dogs on the third day. By analogy, if there are Ⅲ sick dogs in the village, the owner of the sick dog will see ⅲ-1 sick dog, when it found that no one killed his dog before ⅲ-1 days, then it can infer that his dog is sick dog, so as to kill his dog on the first day. On the other hand, if there is a gunshot on the third day, there are Ⅲ sick dogs in the village.

context: On average, the educated person today spends significantly less time reading books than the educated person did fifty years ago, yet many more books are sold each year than 50 years ago
question: Each of the following statements helps to explain the above phenomenon except which one
A: People 50 years ago spent A lot of time reading a book and often read a book for a long time, but now most people read the general idea of it and do not understand it very well
B: People were more likely to borrow books from libraries 50 years ago than they are now
C: Books today tend to be thinner and easier to read than they were 50 years ago.
D: People 50 years ago were more likely to display their education and taste by collecting large quantities of books than they are now
explanation: Contradiction: The contradiction between people reading less now than they did 50 years ago and selling more books than 50 years ago. People 50 years ago preferred to collect books, so it is only right that more books were sold 50 years ago than now.

context: A device that detects counterfeit money lights up red when it detects a counterfeit note, and the manufacturer says there is only a 0.1 percent chance the device will mistake a real note for a fake. As a result, the instrument will detect counterfeit notes 599 times out of 1,000 times when the red light goes on
question: The reasoning of the above argument is wrong because
A: ignores the possibility that the red light will not go on in the presence of the counterfeit money
B: generalizes a general conclusion based on one potentially biased case
C: ignored possible human error by the operator of the instrument in detecting counterfeit currency
D: The concept of data was changed when discussing percentages
explanation: 0.1% from the premises is a concept of possibility, which has been replaced by a concept of necessity in the conclusion

context: As long as there is no fog, the plane takes off on time.

D: Ⅰ, Ⅱ and Ⅲ. ⅰ. There was no fog, but the plane didn't take off on time. ⅱ. It was foggy but the plane still took off on time. ⅲ. Fog, flight delay.
explanation: Explanation “:“ To explain that the condition of the explanation is untenable, it must be satisfied at the same time: first, confirm the previous; Second, negate the latter. I affirm the former and negate the latter, indicating that the conclusion of the subject is not valid. Both Ⅱ and Ⅲ are negative, which can't explain that the question is not valid.

context: The full fare on Western airlines from Beijing to Xi 'an has remained unchanged for more than a year, but currently 90 percent of the tickets on Western Airlines from Beijing to Xi 'an are sold at a discount and only 10 percent at a full price: a year ago it was half at a discount and half at a full price. B: The current discount fares on Western Airlines from Beijing to Xi 'an are basically the same as they were a year ago

context: There is an increasing number of Chinese computer software that corrects vocabulary, grammar and punctuation errors, allowing journalists to write without having a good grounding in Chinese. Therefore, schools training journalists do not need to pay attention to the improvement of students' Chinese ability, but should focus on the cultivation of other qualities of journalists.
question: Which of the following, if true, most weakens the argument and proposal above?
A: Avoiding mistakes in vocabulary, grammar and punctuation does not necessarily ensure the quality of your text.
B: The journalism course emphasizes and requires students to be proficient in using computers and familiar with various kinds of software.
C: The more effective Chinese software is, the more likely it is to be pirated.
D: D: The establishment of a new course in the journalism school has to go through complicated procedures of verification and approval
explanation: First, summarize the conditions of the problem. There are more and more Chinese computer software which can correct the mistakes in vocabulary, grammar and punctuation (argument 1) → Journalists do not have a good foundation of Chinese, which does not impede their writing (argument 2) → Journalism colleges should not pay attention to the improvement of students' Chinese ability, but to the cultivation of other qualities of journalists (Conclusion) This argument includes two arguments and one conclusion. Argument 1 is the second argument; Argument 2 is the argument of the main argument and the conclusion of argument 1. In the second step, argument 2 is based on the assumption that avoiding errors in vocabulary, grammar, and punctuation will ensure the quality of the text

context: There has been a lot of talk about an earthquake happening in recent times. One evening, Xiao Ming asked his grandfather who was enjoying the shade in the yard, “Grandpa, they all say there will be an earthquake tomorrow.“ Grandpa saiAccording to my observation, it is not inevitable that there will be no earthquake tomorrow.“ Xiao Ming said: “So you mean there won't be an earthquake tomorrow?“ Grandpa said, “That's not true.“ Xiao Ming is confused.
question: Which of the following words is closest to the meaning of grandpa?
A: There must be no earthquake tomorrow.
B: There may be an earthquake tomorrow.
C: There may not be an earthquake tomorrow.
D: Tomorrow is impossible without an earthquake.
explanation: No earthquake is necessary ↓ is equivalent to: earthquake is possible. So Grandpa means: there may be an earthquake tomorrow.

context: The more cholesterol and fat a person consumes from their diet, the higher their serum cholesterol indicator. There exists a limit at which the two are in direct proportion. Beyond this limit, serum cholesterol levels rise only slowly, even with a sharp increase in cholesterol and fat intake. This threshold is the same across ethnic groups and is about a quarter of the average European's cholesterol and fat inta
question: Which of the following conclusions is best supported by the above statement
A: Per capita cholesterol and fat intake in China is 1/2 of that in Europe, but per capita serum cholesterol index in China is not necessarily equal to 1/2 of that in Europe
B: The above limits can be reduced by reducing the intake of cholesterol and fat
C: three quarters of Europeans have serum cholesterol levels above normal levels
D: If the intake of cholesterol and fat is controlled within the above limits, the normal serum cholesterol level can be ensured
explanation: A person's intake of cholesterol and fat is unconditionally proportional to his serum cholesterol index. Then, if the per capita intake of cholesterol and fat in China is 1/2 of that in Europe, the per capita serum cholesterol index is also equal to 1/2 of that in Europe. However, it is concluded that the limit is 1/4 of the average cholesterol and fat intake in Europe, and within this limit, the above two become 1/2 of that in Europe, but the average serum cholesterol index in China is not necessarily equal to 1/2 of that in Europe. Therefore, it can be concluded that the per capita intake of cholesterol and fat in China

context: “As long as the sun is shining and the temperature is below zero, there are always a lot of people in the street wearing leather jackets. As long as it's raining and the temperature is above freezing, there are always people in the street wearing raincoats. Sometimes it is sunny and raining at the same time.
question: If the above statement is true, which of the following must be true
A: Sometimes people in the street wear raincoats over leather jackets.
B: If there are a lot of people in the street wearing leather jackets and it isn't raining, there must be sun in the sky.
C: If the temperature is below zero and there are not many people wearing leather jackets on the street, it will rain.
D: If the temperature is above zero and no one is wearing a raincoat on the street, it must not be raining
explanation: 1 There is a sun in the sky and the temperature is below zero → There are always a lot of people wearing leather jackets on the streets; 2. It's raining and the temperature is above freezing → there are always people wearing raincoats on the streets; 3 Sometimes, there is sun in the sky but it rains at the same time. People wear raincoats.

context: At the beginning of the year, in order to motivate employees to work hard, a company decided to select the “Star of the Month“ according to their monthly performance. In the first 10 months of the year, Wang was named “Star of the Month“ for exactly four consecutive months. His other three colleagues, Zheng, Wu and Zhou, also achieved the same feat. As for the months in which these four people were selected as “Star of the Month“, it is known that: (1) Wang and Zheng were selected at the same time in only three months; (2) Zheng and Wu were elected at the same time for only three months; (3) Wang and Zhou were not elected in one month; (4) Only two were elected simultaneously in July; (5) At least one was elected in January.
question: According to the above information, in which month was Mr. Wang elected“ Star of the Month “?
A: March-June.
B: April-July.
C: May to August.
D: July-October.
explanation: From conditions (1) and (2), we can find that the months in which Wang, Zheng and Wu were elected are consecutive, and the number of different months is not more than 6. Therefore, Wang, Zheng and Wu cannot be elected in January, otherwise condition (4) is violated. Therefore, Zhou is elected in January, that is, the months in which Zhou is elected are from January to April. ② The month in which Wang was elected is: May to August, June to September, or July to October. The month in which Wang was elected cannot be July-October, otherwise Zheng was elected in June-September, and Wu was elected in July-October or May-August, violating condition (4).

context: ZTE Group is recruiting 20 middle managers, the least likely to be hired is a college degree or below, or no management experience at all, while people who understand English or Japanese are more likely to be hired.

A: Mr. Zhang is 40 years old, graduated from a technical secondary school. B: Ms. Wang is an associate professor at the School of Economics and Management with a master's degree. She has published monographs on management and used to be a public relations trainee manager in a shopping mal
C: Ms. Liu received her bachelor degree from the School of Foreign Languages in 2000. After graduation, she worked as a foreign-related tour guide for half a year and a full-time translator for two years. Proficient in English and Japane
D: Lao Sun used to be the president of the famous Southbound Group. He was once known as a legendary self-made entrepreneur with no education and no background. Because the collapse of Southbound Group forced him to start his own business
explanation: Step 1: Grasp the main information of the explanation. The candidate must have a college degree or above as well as managerial experience. People who know English or Japanese are more likely to be hired. This means that knowledge of English or Japanese is not necessary. Step 2: Judge the effect of each choice. In A, Mr. Zhang only has a technical secondary school education, which does not meet the requirements of “must have a college degree or above“; In B, Ms. Wang has a master's degree, has published management monographs, and has experience as a public relations trainee manager in a shopping mall, which meets the requirements of “must have a college degree or above and management experience“. C Miss Liu has no management experience, so she does not meet the requirement of “must have management work experience“. D) She has no education, so she must have a college degree or above

context: The Y component of commercially available brand X cigarettes was found to inhibit the Epstein-Barr virus. Experiments have confirmed that the Epstein-Barr virus is a strong nasopharyngeal carcinogen, causing normal nasopharyngeal cells to transform into cancer cells. Therefore, people who regularly smoke branded cigarettes will reduce their risk of developing nasopharyngeal cancer
question: Which of the following, if true, most weakens the argument abo
A: Experiments under different conditions can lead to similar conclusions
B: Patients who already had nasopharyngeal cancer did not find improvement after smoking X brand cigarettes
C: Regular smoking of brand X cigarettes enhances the inhibitory effect of the Y component on Epstein-Barr virus
D: The effect of component Y can be neutralized by component Z of brand X cigarettes
explanation: Although the Y component of X brand cigarettes can inhibit EB virus, the effects of Y component, including the inhibition of E virus, can be neutralized by the Z component of X brand cigarettes. Therefore, based on the Y component of X brand cigarettes can inhibit EB virus, it cannot be concluded that people who regularly smoke X brand cigarettes will reduce the risk of developing nasopharyngeal cancer. This strongly weakens the argument of the question Stem.

context: Only planting trees and grass can prevent soil erosion
question: Which of the following can be deduced from the above statement?

B: If soil erosion is not prevented, plant trees and grass
C: Preventing soil erosion is the basis of planting trees and grass
D: If there is no planting of trees and grass, soil erosion cannot be prevented
explanation: Prevent soil erosion (P) → plant trees and grass (Q). A: Plant trees and grass (Q) → prevent soil erosion (P). B: Do not prevent soil erosion (-P) → plant trees and grass (Q). C) Planting trees and grass → preventing soil erosion (P). D: No planting trees and grass (→Q) -- no preventing water and soil erosion (-P) -- no preventing water and soil erosion (P) -- planting trees and grass (Q)

context: In the era of fragmentation, people's attention is difficult to sustain, so it has become a constant effort for marketers to keep users on the email page for longer. explanation: From the explanation, giFs can increase the visual impact in the email, and we can get the conclusion that the GIF dynamic picture inserted into the email can attract the user's attention and increase the user's click rate.

context: An international conference was held at a certain university. In one of the roundtables, five experts in related fields from several countries participated. explanation: Permutation and combination. A is German and speaks French, so A should be next to a Frenchman or a French speaker C or a German speaker E, so rule out C and D. B is Chinese and speaks English, so B should be next to English C and Chinese E. Rule out A, so choose B.

context: Sometimes in life you can see some people will repeatedly wash their hands, repeatedly sterilize the tableware, repeatedly check the door lock and so on, repeat this kind of meaningless action and make themselves feel very annoyed and bitter, this is one of the neurosis, called obsessive-compulsive disorder. context: In order to increase labor productivity, some manufacturing companies have recently optimized their production processes in order to employ fewer assembly line workers to produce more products.
